idGroup.fg: I want to tell the story of this man Wili Santo, he told it to me long ago.
It tells of two Erromangan people.
One has a wife. When they were married they did not leave each other.
They stayed until one day this one with a wife went walking with her.
They went to see a friend of theirs.
They talked with his friend. He had a pig.
The pig was a female pig.
The man who had a wife looked at the pig which was digging the ground.
And he said to the other, "I see your wife knows how to work well.
But my wife doesn't work well.
Sometimes I ask her to do this, I tell her but she doesn't do it, but your wife works well.
If you want, I'll give you my woman but you give me your woman."
And the other who owned the female pig said, "Oh very good. If you exchange it could be good.
I will give you my woman, but you will give me your woman."
The man said, "Oh it's good."
When he was with the other's woman he hurried with the woman and they went a long way to his house.
But the other one took his woman, the woman pig, and they went to his house.
Then the exchange was finished. When he went with his wife, his child said, "Eh, you've made some food we can eat, and we will stay."
The pig dug and made a mess of everything inside the house.
The man looked for a long time. And he felt bad and said, "Eh, get some food for us to eat, but you don't listen to me, you don't prepare the food.
You look out, I am going to hit you."
You know how animals are, it didn't understand what the man said to it.
It did what it wanted to and spoiled everything inside and the man felt bad about it and said,
"If you keep doing this then I am going to hit you sometime."
And one day he said she should make something, she should make the place ready.
In the kitchen. She should make ready inside the house, she should cook food for them to eat. She doesn't want to.
Because the pig can't know language that we, people, would speak.
He felt bad about the pig and he hit it and killed it.
And that is the end of the story I have told.
He told that there was this ancestor who had a son, he and his wife.
But his wife died, and the father and son were left.
Until this old man became old and he called his son.
His father said, "Come here, I want to talk to you." The boy went to see his father.
And his father said to him,
"We are both here but when ['you' corrected to 'I'] I may die.
Some day you will bury me.
And you will come to look after my grave.
If you see a tree growing from my grave.
don't pull it out. But look after it until it bears fruit."
They waited and the father died, and the child went to bury his father.
But he didn't forget his father's story.
He waited a while then he went to his father's grave. But he didn't see any tree growing out of his father's grave.
He stayed until he went back to the grave and saw a small tree
growing from his father's head.
And he looked after it until that tree bore fruit, and it was a coconut.

itmGroup.ti: Tata Sailas go tuluk inru—Tata Silas and the two tuluks

idGroup.fg: Okay, now I will tell this one. This is a story about
us, Limas and me. I came and got married and stay at this place,
until I had a wife and a child. One day,
I thought about my father and mother. "I will visit them at Eratap." And I went.
I got there and they told me, "Our sugar is finished."
I tell them, "Tomorrow morning I will get you some sugar."
I say, "I will go and visit tata Sailas." I go to see them, they talk, I talk and talk..
And I came back and saw my father and mother. I said to them, "I will go, but tomorrow morning I will bring sugar for you."
I came by canoe, landed by Ear passage, the canoe there. And I said to them, "Don't take the canoe.
The canoe should be there. And tomorrow morning then I will go and get sugar for you."
I come and I tell my wife, "Apu and Ati have no sugar".
We will prepare sugar for them, we'll get some bread.
Early morning I left Erakor, and came ashore at Egis,
take the passage at Ear to give them sugar.
I'll go and my mother and the others said, "And did you go to see Mister Sailas?
And did he say anything or not?" I said, "Nothing".
And they tell me, "He had a feast last night and danced until daylight."
And I called out for James. He is small, he is around I don't know how old, he is very small.
I called James, "You come quickly!" He comes and stands, I tell him, I say,
"You go to Elaknaar. And you go see Apu and Ati and you tell them, 'Uncle from Erakor is there
but he said he wants only one tuluk, he doesn't want two.' They will give you only one tuluk. You bring it. I will eat it."
The man and the woman stayed on and then old Silas said to his wife, "Hey, is there any tuluk left?"
The woman didn't talk, she stayed quiet. This went on until the husband said, "I'll tell you a story from the old people.
A small stone can wreck a big canoe."
The woman stayed and felt around in the oven and found two tuluks.
She wanted to get them. She said, "Here are the tuluks." She says to them, "Now I'll go and look at the slave at Erakor."
A story straight from the old people. She took the tuluk and she came back to the house.
She went inside and said to this slave, "What have you been doing until you ask for tuluk?"
"I went and tried because we laughed because he was my father, but I wasn't scared because he told his story to me many times." That's the way of the old people.
And he told me like this, he told it like this.
A story from the old people that he told, to James. He said, "Did he say anything?" He said, "Nothing". And this is the story they told me which I have told.
"A small stone can break a big canoe." Every time someone wants to go to the ocean. You push your canoe into the passage.
You push your canoe. You look at that stone. That stone is big.
But that stone is really small. When you want to go you look at the big stone.
You go around the big stone to get out to sea, you don't believe the small stone (could damage the canoe). When you come back you drag your canoe
ashore, the small rock breaks your canoe. And you won't be able to use your canoe anymore
Your canoe is broken, you must plug up the hole. That's the end of the story that I have told you. Thankyou.
Once there was a grandfather and grandmother
They made their house a long way from the garden
They were there until one time they wanted to go to their garden one day.
They carried everything for their garden and they went.
They got their knife, their axe, and their basket which they would fill with everything, then they went.
They went close to their garden and a big pig came near.
The big pig came and chased them (the two old people).
The pig chased them
They ran and ran until they reached the house
Then the man began to get everything ready.
He got his spear, bow and arrow ready.
And he got his axe and knife, and went back. He told his wife, "You stay, but I will go back to the garden, to look for the big pig that chased after us."
When he got to the garden he began following the pig's tracks.
He followed its tracks until it was dark, deep darkness was coming in.
He went on until he got to the edge of a cave.
It was getting darker and the man wanted to go inside the cave, and then he would sleep the night until the morning when he would follow the tracks again.
But as he stayed and stayed.
He felt around the cave that he got into. As he felt around he heard something.
He heard something, "Oh". He thought, "What's that?" He felt around until he touched something and he listened and heard that it was a man.

He said, "Hey, but how did you get into this cave?" The man who was inside the cave said, "But you, how did you come here?" And the man spoke, he said, "We, my wife and me, we went to our garden, but a big pig chased us.
So we returned to the house, and I prepared and I came here for it.
But you know that that big pig is not a pig.
But that big pig is a devil.
But it took off its skin and changed to wear the skin of a man."
When he said this to the devil, the devil said, "Ah but I wanted to eat you, but you ran away.
But now we'll wait until you are asleep and then I will eat you."
But the devil didn't tell the man. The devil was thinking about how to kill the man at night.
They stayed until it grew dark, then the darkness fell on the ground.
until the middle of the night, and the devil said, "Have you eaten already?".
And the man said, "I still have not eaten."
When the man followed the tracks of the pig while it was still daylight, he saw a navele tree.
He cut a navele nut.
He cut the navele and he filled up his basket with them.
When the two went, the devil said, "They've gone to eat at night."
It was the middle of the night. When they ran away to the bush they ran to get food.
The man thought they would go and eat taro and yam and banana and some food which he thought they would go and eat.
The devil said, "You climb here?" They climbed up the fig tree.
The devil carried some figs and ate them.
He told his grandfather, "You take the food and eat."
When his grandfather heard, he said, "Hey, but I can't eat Nait figs."
As the devil ate the fig, grandfather took out the navele from his basket and ate it.
Grandfather ate quickly. When they were there for a while the devil asked, "How many men have you eaten?" And the man said, "What about you?" The devil said, "I have eaten three men."
"And you?" And the man said, "I have eaten eight men."
The devil stopped and thought, "I thought about this and I am a little worried.
He said, "I want to eat this man here, but now he has eaten eight men.
But I have only eaten three men.
And now he might hit me."
The devil thought and thought and thought. He was up on the Nait tree, he fell and he broke the branches and wore them like clothes as he fell down.
When he broke the fig branch he fell down and the bush was broken and he was scared of this man.
He ran away and then the man sat and worried.
When the devil escaped the man came down and broke the bush up to the house.
And that's where the story finishes.

itmGroup.ti: Map̃er, the fish that hides (Apu Ntan's story)

idGroup.fg: The story of Apu Ntan, mister Kalpong of Eratap [he died in 1922].
The fish said, "We have many fish, but this fish, the map̃er, is a small one and it doesn't want to see light or be in a bright place.
But when he follows the beach he hurries to escape and hide in a place among stones.

So, when the fish follows the beach, you see it hurry to escape to its place. It moves its tail quickly, after when it appeared at the stone, it was not ashamed. The meaning of Apu Ntan's story is very good.
He said, "He is like the fish they call map̃er, his many bad works are out in the open."
Prayer 1: He kills, 2: He steals other women, 3: He steals, 4: He commits adultery. But when Christianity comes all his bad work is out in the open.
The beach is in light, the stone is in darkness and it is the map̃er.
I want to tell this small story.
1933 when I was, we were in the English Police.
This man who was the District Agent on Santo, Hog Harbour was called Mister Salisbury.
January 1933, Charlie Naot was the lance corporal. Together with Ruben, Simeon, Kalsaopa and me, Kalsarap.
We left Vila and we went to Weso, Malakula and SS Morinda got stuck. And we stayed that whole day at Weso, Malakula.
They took some cargo from the front and put it at the back of the Morinda.
SS Morinda, and when the high tide came in, and the boat floated and we left for Tangoa, Santo
We stayed at Santo. We anchored, and it was dark. In the morning they left us, Tangoa island.
We didn't know who would take us to east Hog Harbour
January fifth 1933, Lindsay Macmillan took their launch and came and took us to Kanal (Lugainville).
Namber seven we stayed at Shark Bay on Monday and we reached Hog Harbour.
On the fourteenth the Saint Andre anchored at Hog Harbour.
28 January 1933 and they shot a bushman
in the hills. Mister Salisbury was there. Sunday they carried him down to the seaside.
Our boss said, "We'll put him in the hospital at Luganville"
Friday 27th and word came that Limok died at Erakor.
The fourth of February 1933 we went to visit Lindsay's place between Hog Harbour and Port Olri.
This was our work, some days we worked, some days we went walking about.
January 1933 this was, February fifth, La Perouse anchored at Hog Harbour.
1933, and the SS Makambo anchored at Hog Harbour.
Anchored, February 12th, at Port Olry.
March 18th, the SS Morinda came and anchored at Hog Harbour. April 1st and 2nd the La Perouse anchored at Hog Harbour again.
On the fifth day it was raining. Some of us didn't go to work, we finished and all stayed at home.
And on the ninth the boss gave us a dynamite so we dynamited fish.
We went fishing in the sea until we had dynamited 46 karong.
The 19th of May, SS Makambo came and anchored at Hog Harbour.
The 20th of May we saw this place, Blue Water.
Then, on June 4 1933, we left Hog Harbour and we came back to Vila.
Sunday it was raining heavily, we slept at Shark Bay on the fifth and on the sixth we stayed at Mafea island.
On the seventh we were at Tangoa, then on the twelfth we stayed at Vila, we took the SS Morinda to get to Vila. That's all.

itmGroup.ti: Kalsarap's time in the English Police

txGroup.tx: Amurin nag amertil naliati nag komam utok plisman. Komam nen upak Emlakul, 1934.

idGroup.fg: I want to tell about when we were police. We went to Malakula in 1934.

txGroup.tx: Lans koprel, Jimmy Takaye, Praivet Jon Lisbet, go Naser. Rupi teni Hog Haba, Santo.

idGroup.fg: Lance corporal Jimmy Takaye, Private Jon Lisbet, and Naser. They were from Hog Harbour, Santo.

txGroup.tx: Praevet Ruben, Ben, Kalsrap. Komam upi teni Erakor.

idGroup.fg: Private Ruben, Ben, Kalsrap. We were from Erakor.

txGroup.tx: Sem go Kalfao, rapi teni Ep̃ag.

idGroup.fg: Sam and Kalfao were from Pango.
We left Vila on the eighth of September 1934.

txGroup.tx: Upan ntan Busman's Bei. // Ulek mista Adam go mista Harrison ranru to esum̃ ni mista Adam. // Namba naen September ipi miting ni Efil.

idGroup.fg: We landed at Bushman's Bay. // We saw Mr Adams and Mr Harrison at Mr Adams's house. // On the ninth of September, there was a meeting at Vila.
On the tenth we stayed at Petenter, Malakula.
On the 15th October we went to Lakaskas.

txGroup.tx: Aliat toknak, kineu, Kalfau, Reuben, upan lel naik, Krapei.

idGroup.fg: On Saturday, I, Kalfau and Reuben went looking for fish, for Krapei.

txGroup.tx: Namba sikstin, miting ni Efil. Namba naentin September, Jimmy Takaye, Jon Lisbet, Sem, Ruben,

idGroup.fg: On the sixteenth there was a meeting in Vila. Number 19 September, Jimmy Takaye, John Lisbet.
Sam, Ruben, Kalfau, Kalsrap, Naser.

txGroup.tx: Aliat toknak Ruben go Ben go Kalfau rupan sari.

idGroup.fg: Saturday, Ruben and Ben and Kalfau went walking.

txGroup.tx: Namba twentetri, 1934 aliat tap, miting ni Eratap.

idGroup.fg: On the twenty-third, 1934, Sunday, meeting at Eratap.

txGroup.tx: Namba twentefo aliat Mande, utu Ajen. Ufak nananre, nort Emlakul.

idGroup.fg: On the twenty-fourth, Monday, we were at Atchin. We went to the side, north Malakula.

txGroup.tx: Namba twentesiks, SS Makambo itorwak Ajen, utu naor naliati nen aliat tap.

idGroup.fg: On the twenty-sixth, SS Makambo anchored at Atchin, we stayed there on Sunday.

txGroup.tx: Namba torti, miting ni Erakor. Utu raki utu Ajen raki

idGroup.fg: On the thirtieth there was a meeting at Erakor. We waited at Atchin for

txGroup.tx: lons kefo mos mam pak nanre ni nort Emlakul.

idGroup.fg: the launch to take us to north of Malakula.

txGroup.tx: Namba wan Oktober, go utao Ajen, raki nort wes of Malakula.

idGroup.fg: October first we left Atchin to go to north-west of Malakula.

txGroup.tx: Upan torwak Tontar, naor ni Malapar namba wan.

idGroup.fg: We anchored at Tontar, at Malapar, on the first.

txGroup.tx: Namba tu Janweri raru upak Tanmaru.

idGroup.fg: On the second of January, the boat got to Tanmaru.

txGroup.tx: Namba siks, Espigel Bei, Emlakul go Malua Bei.

idGroup.fg: On the sixth, Espigel Bay Malakula and Malua Bay.

txGroup.tx: Namba siks, Ruben, kineu go Sem // ulek natam̃ol malik inru rusir ramat to elau. Utao rato me tuipan utap tankir mau nlaken ranap̃o top. Natam̃ol malik nen rutakot natuen kaaru. Utap tae mau ruslati pan pami ko? //

idGroup.fg: On the sixth, Reuben, Sam and I // saw the two heathen who had been shot dead on the beach. We left them there, but we didn't bury them because they stank too much. The heathen cut the leg off one of them. We didn't know if they took it to eat it or not.//

txGroup.tx: Esuan rusosoki Spigel Bei. // Namba siks rutp̃il nasum̃ ni nam̃er taar nlaken SDA itokes. Nam̃er malik nen rusu mai, rutp̃il nasum̃tap ni SDA, rutp̃il, ruporp̃rai

idGroup.fg: The place they call Spigel Bay. // On the sixth they burned the white people's houses because the SDA were there. These heathen came down and burned the church of the SDA, they burned and broke

txGroup.tx: pija rol, go slet, paipol, ipi nanrogtesan p̃ur. Natam̃ol kenen rupak Aore, nlaken nanrogtesan ipi nanrogtesan p̃ur. Namba seven Oktober, ipi miting ni Ep̃ag, go usak pak Tanmaru, natkon ni nam̃er malik.//

idGroup.fg: the picture roll, the slate and the bible, it was a big disaster. These people went to Aore, because it was such a big disaster. On the seventh of October there was a meeting at Pango and we landed at Tanmaru, a heathen village.//

txGroup.tx: Go usak pak Tanmaru, natkon ni nam̃er malik. Utao Dinamit go umatur Dinamit. // Ipiatlak ntawot natam̃ol ruto esan umaturwes. //

idGroup.fg: We left Tanmaru and we slept at Dinamit. // There were human bones around the place where we were sleeping. //

txGroup.tx: Utokleg p̃ulp̃og, go upak Makawe, natkon kia nag katli. Makawe, Piter, go Amok.

idGroup.fg: We stayed until day break and we went to Makawe, the village I spoke about. Makawe, Piter and Amok.

txGroup.tx: Amok, ipi np̃aur, ipi hedkwota nig natkon // nran ruentafkir. Go Mista Adam inrik mam kin nag, "Kofai polet sisi negamus." Selwan tukfan paakor kotap to naor keskei mau, me tukfan ifwel rukfei sisi go ipi mal negamus. //

idGroup.fg: Amok was the main village, headquarters of the two villages. // And Mister Adams told us, "We'll put bullets in our guns." When we appear, we will scatter [so we're not an easy target] then we'll go, if they pull out guns then it will be every man for himself. [Lit: it will be your time].//

txGroup.tx: Utao Amok // go Mista Tam inrik Kali naot ni Amok kinag, "P̃atu mam tete naat kefei ki mam pak Lefenpis." Selwan upan kailek nra. Go natam̃ol nen inag keler go naot itli nag, "P̃atap ler mau."

idGroup.fg: We left Amok // and Mister Adams told chief Kali (chief of Amok), "You give us some men to guide us to Lefenpis." When we went we saw blood. And the man said he would go back and the chief said, "Don't go back."

txGroup.tx: Go inag, "Malfanen aletae nra ita pi wak mau me ipi nra natam̃ol." Go Mista Tam ipulu sisi sees ilaukin ntakun. Natam̃ol ne kipei selwan upa paakor natkon ulek naot ni Lefenpis itarp̃ek to esum̃ nega to nlaken utaptae fei isi mau go koimatur skoti.

idGroup.fg: And he said, "Now I can see that this is not pig's blood but it is human blood." And Mr Adams took out his revolver and put it to the man's back. This man led us when we came to the village we saw the chief of Lefenpis fallen at his home, but we didn't know who shot him. We stayed there with him.

txGroup.tx: P̃ulp̃og go rupo sol naot nega mos pak elau. Rupau naul naniu ipi napor go rupo pai naot negarwes. Raru imai msagi pak hospitel ni Kanal Santo.

idGroup.fg: In the morning they took the chief to the coast. They wove a coconut leaf basket for him to lie on. The boat came to take them to the hospital at Kanal (Luganville).

txGroup.tx: (Deleted) nlaken rusi nawot ni Lefenpbis. Nawot itli nag,

idGroup.fg: (Deleted) because they shot the chief fro Lefenpis. The chief said,

txGroup.tx: "Komam kufo matur esan, ematol p̃ulp̃og, kofo sel nawot negar pak elau Lefenpis

idGroup.fg: "We will sleep here, tomorrow morning we will take their chief to Lefenpis.

txGroup.tx: go raru kemai msagi, lp̃eki kin hospitel ni kanal. (End of deletion)

idGroup.fg: and the boat came to take him to the hospital at kanal (Lugainville). (End of deletion)

txGroup.tx: Namba ten, utao naor ni Apon, natam̃ol fnau iskei, Mista Paton, ipregi mai. // Upak Tuwalo, Lamlasi, Nefenaila, esan ipi natokon itol, rupi esuan Big Nambas inom wes. Go merler mai. Umatur Lampumpu. P̃ulp̃og ur lanis imai mos mom uler mai pak Tontar naor ni Malopar. //

idGroup.fg: On the tenth we left Apon, the missionary, Mister Paton, came. // We went to Tuwalo, Lamlasi, Nefenaila, these three villages, they are where the Big Nambas villages finish. And back. We slept at Lampumpu. In the morning the launch came and took us back to Tontar, Malopar's place.//

txGroup.tx: To Lampumpu to. Namba 12, uler mai pak Mtanfat, naor ni Malopar, Tontar. // Namba 12 usak pak elag natkon ni maarik Medon rusosoki Tanmililip.

idGroup.fg: Stayed at Lampumpu. On the twelfth we came back to Mtanfat, Malopar's place and Tontar's // we landed up at Mister Medon's village called Tanmililip.

txGroup.tx: Upan p̃og utkal natkon gar p̃ulp̃og rik. Selwan rupilo rulek mam tete rusef me utli nag, "Kota sef mau!"

idGroup.fg: We went at night and got to the village in the early morning. When they woke up they saw us, some ran away but we said, "Don't run away!"

txGroup.tx: Unrikirkin nag upa raki natam̃ol iskei nagien Charlie. Go rutli nag ipan pato matur erfale iskei.

idGroup.fg: We told them we were looking for a man called Charlie. They told us he had gone to sleep in a cave.

txGroup.tx: Go Ben go kineu (Kalsarap) rapo parekin pan natam̃ol iskei ipeiki mam ki napu. Me upa me ipuel.

idGroup.fg: And Ben and I (Kalsarap) went for this man who went ahead of us on the road. Then we went, but he wasn't there.

txGroup.tx: Go ramer ler mai nrik gafman ki go uler mai pak elau Tontar. //

idGroup.fg: And we went back to tell the government and we came back to the coast at Tontar. //

txGroup.tx: Be namba tortin, upak elag, naor ni ... naor iskei rusosoki Tanmililip.

idGroup.fg: But on the thirteenth we went up to the place of ... this place they call Tanmililip.

txGroup.tx: Rutli na ipi naor ni maarik Medon.

idGroup.fg: They said it was the place of Mister Maden.

txGroup.tx: Me p̃ulp̃og, ita malkolik to ulefekor natkon negar, selwan rupilo, rulekmam, tete rusef, me

idGroup.fg: Then, in the morning, before dawn, we went around their village when they woke up, they saw us, some ran away, but

txGroup.tx: komam utli na, "Kotap sefmau, nlaken upareki natam̃ol rusosoki Charlie."

idGroup.fg: we said, "Do not run away because we came for a man called Charlie."

txGroup.tx: Go rutli ito matur, nfalfat iskei, go komam Ben rafopan leka natam̃ol iskei. Iptanki mam upan me ipuel go

idGroup.fg: And they said he was asleep in a cave and we (Ben and I) we went to see this man. He came with us then he (Charlie) was gone and

txGroup.tx: umer ler. Selwan umer mai kailer mai pak elau.

idGroup.fg: we returned. When we came back, we came back to the coast.

txGroup.tx: Elau Santo rusosoki... preg kamp nigmam itkos rusosoki Tontar.

idGroup.fg: The place at Santo where we made our camp was, they call it Tontar.

txGroup.tx: Namba fiftin, go uler mai pak Busman's Bei. Uto Busman's Bei twentewan deis,

idGroup.fg: Number 15 and we went to Busman's Bay. We stayed at Busman's Bay for 21 days,

txGroup.tx: go umer pak tete natkon, naor utok elag Busmans Bei.

idGroup.fg: and we went to some villages up from Bushman's Bay.

txGroup.tx: Namba 22 October, upak natkon rusosoki Rakatambol, Tanmari, Atolpilak.

idGroup.fg: On the twenty-second of October we went to the villages they call Rakatambol, Tanmari, Atolpilak.

txGroup.tx: Umaturwes naliati iskei, go p̃og iskei. // Go Malawut, naot negar, inrik Mista Tam kin nag, "Natam̃ol iskei, nagien Teptep, ito pregsaki nam̃er nigneu nag amragir itosir me nega ipuel. Go Mista Tam inrikirkin nag, "Naot negamus kafo pueti pak elau Busman's Bei."

idGroup.fg: We slept there that day and that night. // And Malawut, their chief, told Mister Adams, "This man, called Tetptep, is causing trouble among my villagers, and he is shooting them, then he disappears." And Mister Adams said to him, "I will take your chief to the coast at Bushman's Bay."

txGroup.tx: "Ifwel Teptep iftap mai mau naot negamus kefo pak kalbus Efil. Me ufpam̃or Teptep kofueti mai go kafo tao naot gamus keler. Me naot Malawut ito pios go Mista Tam inag, "Ko tupaakor natam̃ol nen kutap pestop mau."

idGroup.fg: "If Teptep doesn't come, your chief will go to gaol in Vila. But if we find Teptep, we take him, I will leave your chief to return." Then chief Malowut called out and Mister Adams said, "We will make this man come, don't you shout so loudly."

txGroup.tx: Go komam Sam, rapa pueti me ikelsok nig namet nega go nasum̃ ipi m̃eltig nag ketarp̃ek.

idGroup.fg: And Sam and I went to grab him, but he held on to the window of the house and the house was about to fall down.

txGroup.tx: Go Mista Tam inag raktao go rapotao natam̃ol nen ipan.

idGroup.fg: And Mister Adams said they should leave and they left the man to go.

txGroup.tx: Go rupo plak Teptep mai pak elau p̃ulp̃og kenen. Go Mista Tam ipo tau naot negar ruplake ler pak natkon negar pan. Me Teptep ipak esum̃ malik. // Ulermai marmar naliati ipat.

idGroup.fg: And they took Teptep to the coast that morning. Then Mister Adams let their chief go with them to their village. But Teptep went to the gaol. // We came back and rested for four days.

txGroup.tx: Me namba faef November, aliat Mande,

idGroup.fg: But the fifth of November, Monday,

txGroup.tx: Kalfau go kineu Kalsrap, rapak Unua, naor ni mista Paton.

idGroup.fg: Kalfau and I went to Unua, Mister Paton's place.

txGroup.tx: Namba naen, upak naor ni Per Krekov, go upan nag, "Kulek natam̃ol nig Jermani, iskei, nagien mista Prubak?"

idGroup.fg: On the ninth we went to Per at Craig Cove and we asked, "Have you seen that German man, Mr Prubak?"

txGroup.tx: Me rutli na kimer ler pan. Go umer ler mai pak Krekov.

idGroup.fg: But they said he had gone. And we returned to Craig Cove.

txGroup.tx: Utok Krekov, upak Ranon, ipi Ambrim,

idGroup.fg: We stayed at Craig Cove, we went to Ranon, on Ambrym,

txGroup.tx: upak naor ni Ranon, Makam go ipi natkon ni Amprim.

idGroup.fg: we went to Ranon, Makam and it was a village of Ambrym.

txGroup.tx: Esan ures. Namba ten, upak Pentekos, Melsisi, umatur Lonoro.

idGroup.fg: On the tenth we went to Pentecost, Melsisi, we slept at Lonoro. On the 11th and 12th

txGroup.tx: Laone, me namba 13 utau Laone mai pak Busman's Bei.

idGroup.fg: at Laone, then on the 13th we left Laone to go to Bushman's Bay.

txGroup.tx: Namba 24, komam Ben rapan puet prisen prisona iskei isef // nagien Sulun. Namba 14 go komam Ben rapareki natam̃ol iskei isef. //

idGroup.fg: On the 24th, Ben and I pulled the prisoner out and set him free, // his name was Sulun. On the 14th Ben and I went for this man who ran away. //

txGroup.tx: Ramai puetsoki p̃og, mai pak elau Busmans Bei, uler pak Efil, namba 30 November. // Natam̃ol nen praivet Ruben kin ipi prison gad ilekor wer me isef aliat ipan kaitok natkon nega me itap matur esum̃ mau me aliat ito matur nafrofur.

idGroup.fg: We went to get him at night, came to the sea at Bushman's Bay and we came back to Vila on the 30th of November. // These men, Private Ruben had been guarding, but then they escaped in the day back to his village, but he didn't sleep in his village, that day he slept in the bush.

txGroup.tx: Me p̃og go imai pak natkon ga. Rumai preg repot pak Mista Tam go itli nag, "Komam Ben rakfo pan pueti p̃og go rapopan me atli nag Ben kefo pan puetsoki me inag kineu kin kafopan pueti."

idGroup.fg: That night he came to his village. They came to make their report to Mister Adams and he said, "Ben and I went and I said to Ben to go and get (that man) but he told me I should and get him."

txGroup.tx: Go aponrik natam̃ol nen imai lek mam kin nag, "Ag p̃afei me kafo nrokosik selwan takfan go p̃atulegkin go p̃afak em̃ae me kineu kafo puetsoki selwan rapan natam̃ol nen ipan tu leg kin kaipak em̃ae

idGroup.fg: And I told this man to come and see us, saying, "You lead but I will follow you when we go and you will go a long way, after I will hold him when we go this man will stand up and go away.

txGroup.tx: Go kineu apuetsoki go masmes nega nen ipueti to im̃el. Selwan apuetsoki aslen nen rumau to rusef. Ipiatlak naum sees iskei ito selwan aslen nen rusef rutaos naik iskei rusosoki kaitau.

idGroup.fg: And I held him and his knife fell. When I held him his friends all ran away. There was a small river and when his friends all ran away. There was a small river and when his friends ran away they were like a fish which we call Karong (Trevally in Bislama).
It chases sardines.

txGroup.tx: Komam rapo plak prison nen mai pak elau Busmans Bei rapei pan lek Mista Tam plak prison nen nagien Sulun tu Mista Tam kin.

idGroup.fg: We took him to prison to the coast at Bushman's Bay, we led him to see Mister Adams, with the prisoner whose name was Sulun, to Mister Adams.

txGroup.tx: Go Mista Tam ism̃anri ki naot puluk nrak itol go ramer plak em̃ae pak parik. Ruwatgi go kaitp̃okrorwes.

idGroup.fg: And Mister Adams hit him with a bullock's pizzle whip three times and we took him to the barracks. They hit him and I told them to stop.

txGroup.tx: Utu Tangoa, namba 1 Disemba, Ampai namba 2, Aliat toknak // Umai pak elau Busmans Bei, uler pak Efil, namba 30 November, utu Tangoa, Disemba namba 2, Efil, aliat tap, ipi nametp̃ag nafsan.//

idGroup.fg: We stopped at Tangoa, number 1 December, Ambae number 2, Saturday, // We went to the sea at Bushman's Bay and returned to Vila, 30th November, we were at Tangoa, December number 2, Vila, Sunday, that's the end of the story.//
That's the end of the story.

itmGroup.ti: Kalsarap and a story of a whale

idGroup.fg: When we got to the end of the year we would give the children a present for them to take to their Apu and Ati, a small present they could give to them at Eratap.
The year 1956, we gave them the small present again for them to give to them.
Apu from Elaknar and Apu from Elaau they went to give it, then came back.
After January, Limaas and I wanted to go and visited them.
Pastor Kalagis wanted us to go to Eratap.
We went to Elaknar and Tata Sailas was at his house. When he saw us
and he said, "Webe, small fish they come and eat all the good food.
But the whales will come later.
The whales eat stones then they return."
When Pastor Kalagis heard Sailas' talk he felt bad. But I didn't feel bad.
I already knew that he would tell us the meaning of this story that Sailas told us. And then he told us.
He said one day small fish came would come out to eat
but the whale was hitting the water (with its tail).
But the small fish said now the tide is high
some would go and say he should come." "We will all come and eat at the turn of the tide.
When the tide was out and he returned
and the whale said, "Okay, you eat on the incoming tide.
I will come later." The small fish lay down and ate and the tide went out and they went back.
The whale stayed at sea thrashing its tail
and spurted water until it became hungry. And he thought he would go and eat.
When he came and the tide had gone out, he got stuck and went back.
Okay, when you look around our Efate, you will see whale shit rings the points around Efate.
And we call it whale shit. A story from the old people.

itmGroup.ti: Maal go sokfal—The hawk and the owl

idGroup.fg: One day the hawks were telling stories.
Until they told themselves [....] The hawk said, "I have a herb, I drink it and I know how to fly up high."
And the owl said to the hawk, "You go and get the herbs." And they promised to meet back again. "That is the time you will come."
I will give you herbs, you drink it." They stayed until the time to meet back again, and the hawk brought the herbs.
The owl came, then he told the hawk and mlapuas, "You will get the herbs for him and give it to him to drink it."
Then mlapuas drank the owl's herbs, and he poured water for the owl.
He went and drank the herbs that they got for the owl. He drank it all, but he poured water for the owl and took it to give him to drink.
When he drank it all they met together again, and they said, "Now is the time for us to meet again and we will try to fly."
Until it was the time of the meeting and they met. "Now we will fly."
Then they flew, the owl flew below. He only flew below, but the hawk and mlapuas, mlapuas beat the hawk up high. It is just a short story.
The owl can't fly high because it did not drink the herbs but mlapuas drank the owl's herbs.
Because the owl can't fly high, because it didn't drink the herbs, he flies below, but
mlapuas beats the hawk up high. It is just a short story.
The story of Samuel and Dr.Mackenzie.
When he was about to return to Australia in 1912.
The missionary called Samuel.
He said, "You take your canoe and go to that place Elaknatu"
And Samuel got his canoe and went to Elaknatu.
Dr.Mackenzie said to Samuel, "You see these books? You take them and fill your canoe."
Samuel carried the papers which the missionary had told him about.
Samuel carried them and filled his canoe until it was finished and the missionary asked him, "Is it finished or not?" Samuel said to him, "Yes mis". The missionary said, "Take your canoe and
you paddle out to the ocean." Samuel took the canoe and the missionary ran along the shore to Elignairo and he said to Samuel,
"When you have paddled you'll see I raise my hand you put down your paddle then throw all the paper into the water."
Samuel threw in the paper and went back.
When he paddled to shore at Elaknatu the missionary came to his canoe, but he didn't see any paper and he said to Samuel, "You take your canoe back
to land." The missionary went to his house and Samuel went to Eslaorp̃ur.
I want to tell a story of our old people when Efate was in darkness.
And this chief was at Erkao and he was a 'clever'.
Some days he would walk at night.
Some days he would go to north Efate, some days he would go to Santo or Ambrym or Ambae.
When he came back he called his people to go to the nakamal after he would tell them what he had seen, if it was Ambae, or Ambrym or some island he went to at night.
Yes he can't travel in the day, but he knows to travel at night and his people wanted him to tell them what he'd seen in the village at Ambae or Santo.
Yes and one night he said "I will go to the island of white people." Yes, and he went to Australia. He visited the town.
And he saw a horse which had a cart on it and he called the horse a dog.
He saw people on the roads and many people, and their roads were clean.
He travelled on and saw white women walking around town. When they (the women) walked their hair hid their eyes but when they shook their heads their hair moved back.
And he said, "Are they devils?" He saw cars, the steam boat, a sailing boat with three masts and the steamer, he'd seen all things of the white people.
When he had come back from abroad he called a big meeting and he told them all they should go to the nakamal and he would tell them what he had seen and said,
"Tomorrow you will will come to the nakamal." When they came and he told them what he had seen abroad.
And he said, "There are many white people, they go around on their roads.
But their women's eyes are green like a cat's eye."
They are like devils, their hair is long and if you want you bring them so you can visit them. And they say, "Good, you bring them"
And he said to them, "Good, tomorrow we will go to the passage at Emetfat, after I will get this boat to anchor at Emetfat."
After he said to them, "Good, some of you will marry white women.
And they will show you how they make houses, sailing boats and dogs pulling carts and many other good things I saw. We will have them."
And when they came in the early morning to Emetfat they saw the mast of a sailing boat, small in the distance. They watched until they saw the ship quickly coming in.
It anchored at Emetfat, the people from the boat left, and those on shore looked after them.
When they sit to paddle they turn their backs to the front of the boat then row.
It is not like our canoes where you look at the front of the boat then row.
Yes, when they paddle close to shore and come ashore they say, "White people's eyes are in their backs."
After they will take some women they will all stay on the boat. And they say these people are white like devils.
Because they leave their hair long and their eyes and nose appear behind it, so some of them ran away and hid in the trees and stared at them.
Yes, what the chief said was, "You will marry some white women and they will show you how to make houses and many good things."
And they say they don't want to.
And the chief said, "I think you should try to marry some and they will make our country good and we will live well, also our children's generation in the future." But they don't want to marry them.
And so we will stay the same, generation after generation.
His story is finished.

itmGroup.ti: Man got go taar—The black and white birds

idGroup.fg: When Ep̃ur was in darkness. Ep̃ur is inland from Eton.
When Ep̃ur was in darkness, Christianity was still coming, but the old people of Ep̃ur
used to see two birds appear to them. And it wasn't just one,
but some villages of which they were the main one. This bird was white and the other one is black.
When they are in their village, the white bird flies above,
and they say that the Christians will come to their home.
But if it is a black bird they say it is the heathen coming. This is a true story.

txGroup.tx: Ipiatlak malnen kin tiawi ni Erakor teetwei ruto Ep̃uf to me ipiatlak naot gar ipi nagien Langtatalof, me ipiatlak nmatu inru, iskei nagien Katapel, kaaru ametp̃akor nagien.

idGroup.fg: At that time the old people stayed at Ep̃uf, and they had a chief whose name was Langtatalof, he had two wives, one was Katapel, I forget the other one's name.

txGroup.tx: Naliati ilaap maarik naot ito preg nsaiseiwen.

idGroup.fg: On many days the chief called meetings.

txGroup.tx: Preg nsaiseiwen nrikirkin rukfo til usus natowen gar go teflan kin ruto preg sernale.

idGroup.fg: Have meetings to tell them, to talk about their life and how to do things.

txGroup.tx: Me mal nsaiseiwen go inrik nmatu laap kin na, rukfo preg nafnag wesi pak efare.

idGroup.fg: After the meeting he said to all the women, they should make food and take it to the nakamal.

txGroup.tx: Reki nen kin rukfo tuaal me rukfo fam.

idGroup.fg: They should stay all day and they should eat.

txGroup.tx: Me ser naliati nen kin mtulep Katapel go tekaaru kefreg nafnag kefo preg nafnag me tekatpi kefo pi teni elau ntas.

idGroup.fg: Then, every day Katapel and the other wife made food, but the meat was from the sea.

txGroup.tx: Kepiatlak kai, go kefo piatlak wit, go kefo piatlak naik, go kefo piatlak tefserser ilaap nen ito slati elau, ntas.

idGroup.fg: There was shellfish, and octopus, and fish, and many other things from the sea.

txGroup.tx: Me nmatu laap p̃afo pam̃ori na tekatpi gar ipi teni euut.

idGroup.fg: But the women, you'll see they find the meat along the shore.

txGroup.tx: Ser naliati nen rukfreg nsaiseiwen, mtulep Katapel ipreg nafnag. "P̃afo pam̃ori nag."

idGroup.fg: Every day they had a meeting, Katapel got the food. You'll find out about it now.

txGroup.tx: Tekatpi ipi teni elau ntas, pregi pregi pan me maarik naot ito leka pan me ina, "Mtulep Katapel ga ito pam̃or tekatpi elau itfale?" Ser p̃ulp̃og Katapel isu mai pak etan, ipiatlak nai sees iskei.

idGroup.fg: The meat was from the sea, but the chief watched but he said, 'How does Katapel find meat from the sea?' Each morning, Katapel went down to a small water hole.

txGroup.tx: Nen kin ito mai pai kai ni elau wes.

idGroup.fg: This one from which she filled up with cockles from the sea.

txGroup.tx: Pregi pan pan me maarik naot ina, imurin na ketae itfale, teflan ito mai slat tekatpi ni elau.

idGroup.fg: She kept on doing this until the chief wanted to know how she got the meat from the sea.

txGroup.tx: Trau p̃ulp̃og nen kin kefo pam̃ori teflan mtulep Katapel ito mai pak elau wis tekatpi elau.

idGroup.fg: This morning he went to find how Katapel came from the sea with meat.

txGroup.tx: Me selwan imai p̃ulmatlen imai, kuskor mtulep Katapel.

idGroup.fg: After he came early, he came and hid from Katapel.

txGroup.tx: Malnen mtulep Katapel imai itermau pak eluk sees ga nen, malnen kin ipa kefo mailum nre faat nen itkos.

idGroup.fg: Katapel came near, to her small well, as she went, she slowly turned the stone that was there.

txGroup.tx: Ipai kai ni elau islati em̃rom pan na inom mailum pus faat. Me maarik Langtatalof ina ipam̃ori selwan mtulep Katapel ina iler pa go maarik Langtatalof ina kefo pregnrogo taos mtulep Katapel teflan ito mai slat kai.

idGroup.fg: She filled up with cockles until it was finished, slowly put the stone back. Then Langtatalof wanted to find it when Katapel went back and Langtatalof wanted to try like Katapel to get cockles.

txGroup.tx: Ina ipak eluk sees, nen inre faat. Ipam̃ori na ipiatlak kai, go tefserser laap ni ntas.

idGroup.fg: He went to the well and turn the stone. He found shellfish and other things from the sea.

txGroup.tx: Islati pan na inom, nen kin kemer mailum pus faat keler me itermau tik ki faat nen iler pan.

idGroup.fg: He took it until he was finished, he put the stone back slowly but the stone wasn't put back properly.

txGroup.tx: Go eluk sees ina ito nai itrau pespur, ipur pur pur pan pan go imalig.

idGroup.fg: And the small well just started to get big, until it overflowed.
It overflowed and started to run.

txGroup.tx: Iser ser me mtulep Katapel ito elag ntaf nrogo ki nai iser ifit mai tu leg ki Ewenesu. Isel nawen nen kin ketfag kor nai me, nai ikerkrai top, itrau ser lu ki nawen go imer fit mai to leg ki narfat.

idGroup.fg: It ran and ran, but Katapel was up on the hill and heard the water run right to Ewenesu. She got sand and built a wall against the water but the water was too strong, it flowed over it and the sand, and it flowed down to the bridge.

txGroup.tx: Imer tfagkro itfagkro pan pan inom nai imai imer serlu faat ipa.

idGroup.fg: She went to build a wall until it was finished, the water came near and flowed over the rocks, and kept going.

txGroup.tx: Mtulep imer fit ifit mai ito Efatposfiu itfagkro panpanpan naor sees ito selwan kin nai imai.

idGroup.fg: Katapel ran until she got to Efatposfiu she built a small place was left when the water came.

txGroup.tx: Iser top ina imai kai serlu mtulep.

idGroup.fg: It flowed quickly, it wanted to keep coming, and it flowed over Katapel.

txGroup.tx: Iserlua panpanpan ipato elau, kin go nao ipo mer pak euut slati mai pak euut, me kipe mat.

idGroup.fg: It flowed on until it got to the sea, and a wave came back to shore but she was dead.

txGroup.tx: Kimat go nao ina ito mer slati ler mai slati ler mai kaitasak nagis ni Elakatapel, go rutua nagi nen Elakatapel nlaken mtulep nen ipi Katapel.

idGroup.fg: She died and the wave carried her back and threw her ashore at Elakatapel, and they gave that point the name Elakatapel because of the woman called Katapel.

txGroup.tx: Go iwelkin kufmer us lakun p̃afo pam̃ori na Ewenesu ipiatlak nawen itop nlaken kin ipregnrogo nen ketfagkor nai me nai islatlua.

idGroup.fg: And that's why if you go along the lagoon you will find that Ewenesu has lots of sand because she tried to build a wall to block the water but the water carried her away.

txGroup.tx: Kumai pak brij, ipiatlak naur sees go faat ilaap nlaken kin ina ketfagkro me nai imer slatlua ipa.

idGroup.fg: You come to the bridge, it's a small place with lots of rocks because she wanted to build it, but the water came and took it away.

txGroup.tx: Kumai pak Efatposfiu kupam̃ori na ipiatlak naor sees imaag nlaken kin.

idGroup.fg: You go to Efatposfiu, you see that there is a small open place because of it.

txGroup.tx: Ipregnrogo na ketfagkro me nai imai kerkrai, go islatlua plak faat. Mees p̃apam̃ori na ipiatlak pasis isees m̃as, go natrauswen ni lakun itefla.

idGroup.fg: She tried to build a dam but the water was too strong, and it carried her away with the stones. Today you see the passage there is only small, and that's how the story of the lagoon goes.
It is the little that I know.

txGroup.tx: Amurin nag katil tete natrauswen nen kin aleka, selwan api teesa.

idGroup.fg: I want to tell a story about what I saw when I was a child.

txGroup.tx: Alek tete nam̃er taar nen ruto mai pak esa.

idGroup.fg: I saw some white people who came here.
One was called missionary Trasi.

txGroup.tx: Natam̃ol nen, teni Ertap ruto pan sor kai, go rusor pan pamkin, go rutua pret.

idGroup.fg: This man, those from Eratap sold shellfish, pumpkin, and they gave him bread.

txGroup.tx: Slati mai pami esum̃ mer taf.

idGroup.fg: Took it, ate it at home and came out.

txGroup.tx: Ipi natam̃ol iskei nen kin teni Ertap rufafatwes teetwei.

idGroup.fg: It was a man who those from Eratap believed in, in those days.

txGroup.tx: Atap tae ntau ipi ito Eum̃ mau.

idGroup.fg: I don't know how many years he was at Teouma.

txGroup.tx: Tekaaru, rusosoki Tekrila, kaatol, rusosoki Lekog, nam̃er nen ruto Eum̃.

idGroup.fg: The other, called Tekrila, the third, Lekong, these men were at Teouma.

txGroup.tx: Kafat ipi Telaplan, ga me ito Eum̃.

idGroup.fg: The fourth was Telaplan, he was at Teouma.

txGroup.tx: Nam̃er nen ruto Eum̃. Nrakpei raru nen kin ito mai pak Eum̃ gar mos kopra, rusosoki Perfas, St. Michel,

idGroup.fg: These men were at Teouma. In those days the boat that came to Teouma to carry copra for them, it was called Perfas, St Michel,

txGroup.tx: nagi raru, me nam̃er taar nen, rupiatlak raru ruto mai gar mos kopra Eum̃, teetwei.

idGroup.fg: the name of the boat, the white men took the boat to Teouma to get copra for them in those days.

txGroup.tx: Aleka ki namtak. Ipiatlak nam̃er taar nen amurin nag kagamus trausi konrogo.

idGroup.fg: I saw them with my own eyes. There is a white man that I want to talk to you about, you listen.

txGroup.tx: Ipiatlak natam̃ol taar iskei ito Pelfi teetwei.

idGroup.fg: There was a white man at Belview.
His name was Larso.

txGroup.tx: Larso ito panpan itm̃alu Tekraus imer to nam̃len ipuet imer to nam̃len. Selwan Tekraus ipuet Pelfi go ipi mal wan nafkal ipaakor, 1942. Teni Amerika rupreg Pelfi ipi Bes Ospitel.

idGroup.fg: Larso stayed and then left and there was Tekraus at that place. When Tekraus had Belview it was the time of the war, 1942. The Americans took Belview to be their base hospital.

txGroup.tx: Komam telaap ni Efat umaui weswes Pelfi. Saot pak Not umaui weswes ur Pelfi. Go ipi namagwen p̃ur nigmam. Tenag uleka kafo til tete me akano til silua. Natam̃ol nag rumat go tenag rum̃ol ruto slatir mai psur ospitel ni Pelfi. Marine, army, go navy.

idGroup.fg: Many of us from Efate went to work at Belview. From the south to the north we all worked at Belview. And we were very surprised. We saw some things but I can't tell everything. Some men were dead, others were alive, they put them in the hospital at Belview, marines, army, or navy.

txGroup.tx: Selwan uto weswes uleka ipi namagwen p̃ur. Nigmam tenag uleka itop. Nmaten itokos, tete natam̃ol rumat, me tete rum̃ol mai pak ospitel nen.

idGroup.fg: When we worked there we were always surprised. For us, what we saw was too much. There were corpses and wounded people at the hospital.

txGroup.tx: Tenag rumat rutfeir go rupu nmarter ipan me rupregi ikal ki nakal nega go rupregi iler pak nafanu nega pan. If pi marine, ko if pi navy, ko if pi army.

idGroup.fg: When they died they dressed them in their uniform and they took them back to their country. It might be marines or navy or the army.

txGroup.tx: Tenag rum̃ol rulekor wer tenag ipi mankotik rupak esuan ipi naur ni dokta kefo wesweskir. Tenag rumat ruplak nam̃ler go tenag rum̃ol me negar me rupak esuan dokta itokos.

idGroup.fg: Some lived, some were wounded, they went to the doctor who worked on them. Some died and they went back to their place.

txGroup.tx: Natam̃ol nen kin ruto natikin iskei rusosoki Rossi.

idGroup.fg: The man who lived at the side of Belview was Rossi.

txGroup.tx: Rossi mees ipreg hotel taon Efil.

idGroup.fg: Rossi today has the hotel in Vila.
He had three brothers.

txGroup.tx: Natam̃ol nen kin ruto taon iskei kin rusosoki mista Mi, nega itm̃alu Efil, ipan pak Esanr.

idGroup.fg: The man who stayed in town they called Mista Mi, he left Vila and went to Santo.

txGroup.tx: Ko ito Esanr to panpan imat Esanr, selwan ito Efil, ito Efil pak Esanr, go ipan to Totel Bei.

idGroup.fg: He was there until he died there, at Turtle Bay.

txGroup.tx: Ipi esuan nam̃olien ga inom wes.

idGroup.fg: That was where his life finished.

txGroup.tx: Iskei rusosoki Kipe, Kipe ipreg sto Efil taon.

idGroup.fg: This one they call Kipe, he had a store in Vila.

txGroup.tx: Natam̃ol taar iskei rusosoki Tersat, Franisman, ga ipreg sto go ipiatlak wof, taon Efil.

idGroup.fg: This white man was called Tersat, a Frenchman, he had a store and wharf in Vila.

txGroup.tx: Natam̃ol nen kin rupreg sto p̃ur, iskei rusosoki CFNH, Efil taon.

idGroup.fg: This man had a big shop, called CFNH (Comptoirs Français des Nouvelles-Hébrides) in Vila.

txGroup.tx: Ipiatlak wof go BP, ipiatlak wof ipreg sto p̃ur taon Efil.

idGroup.fg: He had the wharf and BP, the big store in Vila.

txGroup.tx: Natam̃ol nen kin rapreg sto p̃ur taon Efil.

idGroup.fg: These men had shops in Vila.

txGroup.tx: 1927, go sto p̃ur Balan nen isor.

idGroup.fg: In 1927, Ballande caught fire.
Some men were killed there.

txGroup.tx: Selwan rupregsi sto nen, utap tae naftekin ipiatlaken kin sto nen inkap ipami mau.

idGroup.fg: When they destroyed the shop, we didn't know how the shop was completely burned.

txGroup.tx: Me selwan natam̃ol nen rupakes, rumroki na rukfan sol tete mane em̃rom sto.

idGroup.fg: But when these men went, they thought someone had taken money from inside the shop.

txGroup.tx: Selwan rupan go rulakor preg tete namatun ito leg ki esuan mane itkos itefla o atap tae mau.

idGroup.fg: When they went and maybe they were getting something that was right where the money was, or, I don't know.

txGroup.tx: Me selwan rupak em̃rom pan go tenamrun im̃alit, malnen im̃alit, nam̃er laap kin rumat wes.

idGroup.fg: When they went into the building, something exploded and many men were killed.

txGroup.tx: Nam̃er laap nam̃er laap perkati, atai tli, 1927 kin namrun esum̃ p̃ur nen isor, esum̃ ni Palan isor.

idGroup.fg: Many men, I can tell you, in 1927, when the Ballande burned.

txGroup.tx: Tenmatun iskei namrun nen isor, isfeki aian iskei iur elag pan ipan na ip̃rai nmet klas nasum̃tap ni Efil imap̃or.

idGroup.fg: When this place burned, it threw iron high and it broke the glass windows at the church in Vila.
This is a story from before.

txGroup.tx: Selwan p̃ulp̃og komam uto Ertap pa.

idGroup.fg: When we were going from Eratap early in the morning.
We stood and watched the store.

txGroup.tx: Uto maag natam̃ol ruto slati rupa pak ospitel. Tenen rumat tenen rupi mankotik. Ipiatlak natam̃ol ni Ampai iskei, rusosoki Tokolu, ipi Inglis Polis me selwan rukfiit pan,

idGroup.fg: We watched them carry people to hospital. Some were dead, some wounded. There was an Ambae man called Tokolu, in the English police, but when they ran,

txGroup.tx: go namrun nen im̃alit go aian iskei ipregkot natuen atap tae natuen maur ko matu mau, me natuen imakot.

idGroup.fg: this thing exploded and the iron hit his leg, I don't know if it was his left leg or his right leg, but his leg was broken.

txGroup.tx: Apo pa pan pam̃ori 1933 ito ni, ipa ni Kulog weswes Esanr, Sak Bei nanrup̃ naniu ni Kulog.

idGroup.fg: I went and found him in 1933, he went to work for Kulong at Santo, Shark Bay on Kulong's coconut plantation.

txGroup.tx: Mista Mi nen selwan komam upan ulauto etan me ga ipag kin nasum̃ nega.

idGroup.fg: Mister Mi, when we stayed down there, but he went up to his house.

txGroup.tx: Me nasum̃ ne smen ki ipi kava ga.

idGroup.fg: But his house had a cement roof.

txGroup.tx: Selwan isol kamra ga ipan ipak elag pa.

idGroup.fg: When he got his camera he climbed up.

txGroup.tx: Ipato elag go ikamp̃rai kava ne, smen ne malnen itarp̃ek mai imatmal.

idGroup.fg: He went up and he broke the cement roof and fell through and nearly died.

txGroup.tx: Ruslati esum̃ ga rupak Franis ospitel.

idGroup.fg: They took him from his house to the French hospital.

txGroup.tx: Dokta iwesweskin panpan imer m̃ol, imai torik kin po pak Esanr pa.

idGroup.fg: The doctor worked hard on him and he got better, then he went back to Santo.
And that is this small story.

txGroup.tx: Ipi tenag ana kanrik mus ki nen kotae.

idGroup.fg: That is what I wanted to tell you so you would know.
Tagiter (seaslug) is something that cries out for us, when it cries you know it cries out a warning that someone will die.
When you hear it cry at night, it is crying for a man.
Someone will leave, will die.
But as for Taligter.
Taligter is a fish.
It is a fish, when we see Taligter,
When we were children and we see Taligter we are scared because we think it is Tagiter.
Because Tagiter is a devil, it is nothing, but Taligter is a fish.
He is a fish.
He is the same family as eels.
Its ears are black, it has ears.
The way with Taligter, it follows people, you can't play with Taligter.
When you play with it, if you think you will spear it, it will chase you.
And chase you and chase you.
It can chase you a long way.
You can run away, but it will follow you, it will follow your dust trail, but it is a fish.

itmGroup.ti: A story of Rentapau and Erromango

idGroup.fg: I'll tell you about a small place eh?
Erromango. Do you know Rentapau?
Rentapau has a vine there. I have seen it with my own eyes.
A vine ([Bislama] a vine that we call 'natiel').
This vine is there, at the place where, who now, Thanh,
You know, I want to talk about this vine, but
I will talk about a foreign place, and you will listen carefully as I talk, and you will help me with it.
[Bislama] There is this place where Than put his place, at Rentapau.
This one they call Blue Hole.
There's one-, all the old people. I want to tell a story from Erromango.
Everything that came came there to Rentapau came from Erromango
In the olden days the old people from Rentapau, when they wanted something they had to ask
the taboo men from Erromango. If we want something then you have to ask Erromango.
(NT) In language.
(KN) I'll tell it in language? Okay.
They ask Erromango, Erromango will give them everything.
If you want something, Erromango will.
There is a vine at the place which,
Thanh has made his hotel there today [Blue water resort].
There is a vine, a big vine, I've seen it with my own eyes.
It climbs up the mangrove.
And this vine (Bislama) hasn't got a trunk.
You go and look at it where it climbs up the mangroves. (Iokopeth) It is a vine.
(KN) At this place. It is different, you can't find its trunk.
You don't see its trunk.
It is unbelievable, but there was a turtle there, fish, a turtle. They call it a turtle.
It lived in the small pool which Thanh would make (into the Blue Hole resort). Fish would be in it.
It stayed and stayed until they started to clean Rentapau.
And these things ran away back to Erromango.
They are at Erromango until today.
The vine has gone. The turtle has gone.
The most important of this that I want to tell you about today, people go missing at Rentapau.
There is the owner of it who hurts them.
If many of us go there, one will go missing.
And Rentapau has the trunk (of the vine).
Erromangans know, this is how all their things come to Erakor
[corrected to] Rentapau. Rentapau is the head place of all places around Efate.
It is the most taboo place.

itmGroup.ti: A story about George Zachari's life

idGroup.fg: I was born in 1949 on the small island.

txGroup.tx: Apaakor naur Erakor 1949, Erakor, rutil Eraniao.

idGroup.fg: I was born on Erakor island in 1949, it is called Eraniao.
I am from naflak nawi (the yam clan).
But I came out of namkanr (the wild arrowroot clan).

txGroup.tx: Namkanr ipitlak nafrofur iskei ito ftom talm̃at mana.

idGroup.fg: Namkanr has a bush that grows in gardens.

txGroup.tx: Kuleka na inrus pitlak nafte nelepleptau ko nafte itkos.

idGroup.fg: You see it has some spots on it.

txGroup.tx: Go ipitlak temiel go ipitlak tetaar.

idGroup.fg: There is a red one and a white one.
We come out of the white one.

txGroup.tx: Or, nlagwat ni 1959 go government itili komas tato naur sees mau, naur Eraniao.

idGroup.fg: After the cyclone of 1959 the government told us we couldn't stay on the small island.
We should come over here.
We came to the side of the big island.

txGroup.tx: Go malnen kin umai apitlak ntau ten ata pi teesa.

idGroup.fg: And when we moved I was ten, I was still a child.

txGroup.tx: Ntau astat skul malen kin, ore, ata mrotae sef ntau kin astat skul wes mau, me atae kin malen kin apitlak ntau ten.

idGroup.fg: Then I started school, I don't remember which year it was, but I was ten.
I came, I was still at school.

txGroup.tx: Go askul ni Franis, elau Ep̃ag.

idGroup.fg: I went to the French school at Pango.
And I came to school here.

txGroup.tx: Me askul sa, na afnes ki skul sa.

idGroup.fg: I schooled here, then I finished.

txGroup.tx: Go askul Franis pan pan inom.

idGroup.fg: I was at French school, finish.
No more school.
I worked some times.

txGroup.tx: Apei weswes ata mrosok sef ntau mau, aweswes British kafman.

idGroup.fg: I worked, I don't remember what year, for the British government.
When the Condominium was still here.

txGroup.tx: Ore malne ina inom, me kaipiatlak namroan nen amur kafak Bible College.

idGroup.fg: Then I got to think I wanted to go to Bible College.
Of the Assembly of God.

txGroup.tx: Go apak Bible College stat nawesien ni nasum̃tap.

idGroup.fg: And I went to Bible College to start doing Church work.

txGroup.tx: Go apak Bible College ntau itol.

idGroup.fg: I went to Bible College for three years.

txGroup.tx: Ana afnes ki nakte skul, go kaisat diploma nen kin ni Bible College inom.

idGroup.fg: I wanted to finish my school so I took my diploma from the Bible College.

txGroup.tx: Me apei pitlak kos nen kin ato satir, nen kin korespondens nen kin rusent kin ovasis.

idGroup.fg: But first I had correspondence courses which they sent from overseas.

txGroup.tx: Ito America mai, Philippines, go Australia. Ale apas nafet na correspondence nen runeu sent ki, me ato pregi me ato pak skul, pak na Bible College, ale welkia atlasi nen amai pi pastor iskei.

idGroup.fg: It came from America, the Philippines and Australia. I passed the course that they had sent me, and when I had enough of Bible College I became a pastor.
They ordained me.

txGroup.tx: Natam̃ol imat atae tan ki, atae preg naftourien. Apreg Lord's Supper.

idGroup.fg: When someone dies I know how to bury them, or do weddings. I can do the Lord's Supper.
That's all.

itmGroup.ti: The story of the group of children

txGroup.tx: Natrauswen ne rusosoki naferkal. Naferkal ralim iskei.

idGroup.fg: This story is called 'The group of children.' A group of ten kids.

txGroup.tx: Naferkal ga taos ipi teesa, teesa laap rutu naor iskei kin rusosor kir Naferkal.

idGroup.fg: Naferkal is a group of children who are at one place and they call them Naferkal.
Naferkal, ten.

txGroup.tx: Naferkal ralim iskei ruto pan pan go ruto preg talm̃at rulao sernale, rulao nafnag, altuk, ntal, nawi.

idGroup.fg: This group of ten were there and then they made a garden, they planted everything, cabbage, taro, yam.

txGroup.tx: Ale runa ruto panpan go rupam̃or, rule pak elau go rupam̃or raru p̃ur iskei imai.

idGroup.fg: They were there and they looked to the sea and saw a big boat coming.

txGroup.tx: Raru p̃ur iskei imai. Ina imai na itorwak. Ale rusu pak elau.

idGroup.fg: A big boat came. It came and anchored. Ok, they went down to the sea.

txGroup.tx: Runa rusu pak elau, go runa rupakot, rupakot, tete rupakot kram tete rupakot masmes, tete rupakot safel, pik sernale nig talm̃at.

idGroup.fg: They went down to the sea, and they bought, some bought axes and some bought knives, some bought shovels and picks, things for the garden.

txGroup.tx: Pan pan me teesa sees, tenen ipi takrik ga ipaakot ga nalag nen ruto si, mouth organ, ga ipaaktofi.

idGroup.fg: Then a small child, the last child bought a mouth organ for them to blow, a mouth organ, he bought it.

txGroup.tx: Ale malen rupan na rukfreg talm̃at go tep̃afp̃of rupreg talm̃at rulao sernale. Me teses ne ga ito me ito si nalag.

idGroup.fg: Then they went to work in the garden, and the big ones made the garden, and planted things. But the small one stayed and played his mouth organ.

txGroup.tx: Ito si nalag ga ne, panpan me ipiatlak nlak npak p̃ur iskei me ito. Nlak npak ipiatlak ntwam iskei ito em̃rom nlak npak.

idGroup.fg: He blew on the mouth organ, and there was a big banyan tree there. There was a devil living in the trunk of the banyan.

txGroup.tx: Teesa sees nen ina ito si nalag, go ntwam nen inrog wi ki nalag. Ina inrog wi ki nalag go ito mai, ito nrus mai pak m̃eltig, panpanpan

idGroup.fg: The child kept on playing a song, and the devil heard it and liked it. He liked the song and he came out closer and then

txGroup.tx: imai na ilek teesa sees ne go ina, "Atrau nrog wi nalag gaag. P̃amer pregnrogo si." Me teesa sees imer si nalag. Ntwam inrog wi ki. Ale ina,

idGroup.fg: he came to look at the child and he said, "I feel good hearing your song. Try and blow it again." And the small child kept blowing a tune. The devil liked hearing it. Then he said,

txGroup.tx: "P̃apregnrogo tao kapregnrogo gaag si." Ntwam ina isat nalag na isi, trau sati sef. Isati sef pan ale isil npak.

idGroup.fg: "Give it to me so I can try your mouth organ." The devil took it to blow it, but he ran away. He took it and ran inside the banyan.

txGroup.tx: Ale teesa sees nen ito kai. Ikai pan pan go tep̃afp̃of runa ruto rumai paoski na, "Iku kin kuto kai?" Go,

idGroup.fg: Then the small child cried. He cried until the adults came and asked him, "Why are you crying?" And,

txGroup.tx: "Ntwam ito nlak npak ina imai isat nalag neu me kipe sef pa."

idGroup.fg: "The devil in the banyan came and took my mouth organ, and ran away."

txGroup.tx: Ale teesa nen runa ruto rupan stat, runa rukwat ntwam, me ntwam isil to npak, ale rutraf rutraf nako npak.

idGroup.fg: So all the children went to hit the devil, but the devil was inside the banyan, so they dug its roots.

txGroup.tx: Tete rutai ki kram, tete rukli ki pik, pan pan npak nen ikano tarp̃ek.

idGroup.fg: Some cut it with axes, some dug with picks, on and on but it wouldn't fall down.

txGroup.tx: Runa rutraf sees kai mer lag runa,

idGroup.fg: They dug more and then sang,

txGroup.tx: "Napag imarie rie, napag imarie napag imarie rie, napag inawe,

idGroup.fg: [song] Napag imarie rie, napag imarie napag imarie rie, napag inawe,
nawe, nawe nau tagisi.

txGroup.tx: Ale inom go ruimer ruimer pregnrogo ruimer nri npak ne. Ruimer nri npak me rumer nri npak, me npak ikano tarp̃ek, ale ruimer lag:

idGroup.fg: Finished, and they tried again to dig out this banyan. They dug it again and again, but it wouldn't fall down, so they sang again:

txGroup.tx: "Napag imarie rie, napag imarie napag imarie rie, napag inawe, nawe, nawe nau tagisi."

idGroup.fg: [song] Napag imarie rie, napag imarie napag imarie rie, napag inawe, nawe, nawe nau tagisi.

txGroup.tx: Me npak ikano tarp̃ek ale runa ruto. Ale teesa sespal ne ina ito kin ipo pan tai kal iskei, kal altuk.

idGroup.fg: But the banyan would not fall over. The small boy decided to go and cut a digging stick, made of cabbage plant.

txGroup.tx: Ale itai kal altuk iskei. teesa p̃afp̃of runa me kal go ina imailumlum.

idGroup.fg: So he cut the cabbage digging stick. The big children said, "But this digging stick is soft."

txGroup.tx: Komam upregnrogo ki kal p̃afp̃of me ukano nri npak. Me ag kusat kal nen ipi altuk imailumlum go kupo na p̃anri npak ki. Me ina, "Kapregnrogo." Ale rupo ga lag:

idGroup.fg: We tried with a big digging stick, but we couldn't dig the banyan. You brought a digging stick made of cabbage tree, it is too weak and you will try to dig the banyan with it. And he said, "I'll try." And they sang for him:

txGroup.tx: "Napag imarie rie, napag imarie rie, napag inawe, nawe, nawe nau tagisi."

idGroup.fg: [song] Napag imarie rie, napag imarie rie, napag inawe, nawe, nawe nau tagisi.

txGroup.tx: Ale ina ilaoki kal altuk ga, ina inri go npak itarp̃ek.

idGroup.fg: So he dug with the cabbage digging stick, he dug, and the banyan fell over.

txGroup.tx: Npak ina itarp̃ek. Ale, ntwam itaf ale rupuetsok ntwam ale rutaikot nanwen.

idGroup.fg: The banyan fell over. Then the devil left and they held him and they cut his throat.
The story finishes here.

itmGroup.ti: Menal go katom—The barracuda and the hermit crab

idGroup.fg: This story is about the barracuda and the hermit crab.
Barracuda is a fish, and the hermit crab, they were there and
barracuda said, barracuda said to the hermit crab,
"We'll have a race." Barracuda said to hermit crab, "We'll race." And the hermit crab said, "Ok."

txGroup.tx: panpan. Ratil sef naliati kin rakfo stat,

idGroup.fg: So they stayed and stayed. They said which day they would start the race.
But the hermit crab knows that he can't crawl fast like barracuda. Barracuda knows how to go fast.
He can run away quickly, but the hermit crab can't. That day they would race, but the hermit crab first went around every point.
He told his friends who were at each point, he said that day,
"You get ready and when you hear barracuda call out from the water, you call out from the shore."
The day that they said they would start, that they would race, and barracuda said to the hermit crab,
"We'll start at this point, then we'll race to the next point."You'll hear me say, "Wananatajo."
And you will know that I have got to that point. And if you get to the point where I am you say, "Watetjo".
Then barracuda, they started, and he got to the point first. He said, "Wananatajo."
And the hermit crab said, "Watetjo"
They went until they got to the next point and the hermit crab said,
"Wananatajo." Barracuda said, "Watetjo"
Until they got to the point, then the hermit crab who came said,
"This hermit crab, he is a different hermit crab." Because there was a different hermit crab at the second point, and a different hermit crab was at the third point.
But there was only one barracuda. Barracuda ran until he got to the fourth point.The hermit crab said, "Wananatajo."
And barracuda said, "Watetjo." But barracuda's breathing was getting short. He went until he got to this point and the hermit crab said, "Wananatajo." But
But barracuda's breathing was short and he said "Watetjo." Until he got to this point and the hermit crab said, "Wananatajo."
And barracuda said, "Watetjo." They went until his breathing was short. His breathing was short, the hermit crab knew that barracuda was short of breath.
They went on, he went to this point and said, "Wananatajo." And barracuda said, "Watetjo." His breath was short. Until the last point and
the hermit crab said, "Wananatajo." And barracuda said, "Watetjo." Until the last point.
And the hermit crab said, "Wananatajo." And barracuda said, "Watetjo."
And the hermit crab knew that barracuda's breathing was short. And he got to the last point alright and hermit crab said, "Wananatajo."
And barracuda was nearly dead, he couldn't speak at all. His breathing was getting short then he died. And hermit crab knew that barracuda was dead and hermit crab won.
Hermit crab won the race, then hermit crab sent word to every point to get all the hermit crabs to one place to go down to the water where barracuda died at the edge of the water.
Then the hermit crabs went up to barracuda and had a party and ate barracuda all up. The story finishes here.
Children, I want to tell you that respect is a good thing.
Respect your father and your mother.
And your sister and your brother.
As before, in my view, when I first was there, like on Sunday. It wasn't noisy.
You went to church, came back, you sat to eat and you rested, you ate.
And for many days you will do your work, but remember,
the first thing is to listen to the voice of your father and mother. And your days will be many.
That is a little story that wanted to tell you. It is finished here.
Okay, my life, I went to school on the island.

txGroup.tx: Askul naur inom, apak IDS. IDS malen kin rustat wes.

idGroup.fg: I finished school on the island and I went to IDS (Iririki District School). IDS had just started.

txGroup.tx: Ito Iririk, esum̃ ni dokta Frayter elag. Go misis ni dokta Frayter kin

idGroup.fg: It was on Iririki, Doctor Frayter's house up there. And Doctor Frayter's wife

txGroup.tx: iplaksok mom. Ale uto to to panpanpan unom. Ale kaipe nom, kaipe mai tu.

idGroup.fg: taught us. We stayed on there until we finished. I finished then I came back.
We stayed and were doing a little work. Until 1941,
I joined the police.
The French police. I was there in 1941,

txGroup.tx: inom apak Esanr. Ato atlag iskei Efil, apak Esanr pa, kaipe pato Santo to, me seken wol wo ipo maag.

idGroup.fg: finished, I went to Santo. I stayed a month in Vila, then Santo and the Second World War broke out.

txGroup.tx: America rumai me apato Esanr. Go kineu kin apo tu plak America ur

idGroup.fg: America came, and I was at Santo. I took the Americans around

txGroup.tx: ser naor, upreg napu me upan. Askotir atlag itol, uto Suranta.

idGroup.fg: all over the place. We made roads and we went. I was with them for three months, we were at Suranta.

txGroup.tx: Pan pan runrik wou ki, "Kufiar nen p̃afak Solomon?" Ana, "Idipen",

idGroup.fg: Then they said to me. You aren't scared to go to the Solomons? I said, "It depends",

txGroup.tx: nlaken kaipe saen reki Army. Nafkal me apa,

idGroup.fg: because I had signed with the Army. If there is a war I will go,

txGroup.tx: ifpi nmaten. Amat kat kantri. Ale Franis kafman inrogo,

idGroup.fg: maybe I will die. I die for my country. The French government heard this,

txGroup.tx: ale imai msag wou Suranta. Apiatlak sot plisman,

idGroup.fg: and they came and took me me to Suranta. I had a police shirt,

txGroup.tx: kamer plake ler. Ale amai tu,

idGroup.fg: I went back with it. I came,
and then in 1945 I finished.

txGroup.tx: Anom na amai pak Efil, atlag iskei inom go amer pak Tanna.

idGroup.fg: I finished and went back to Vila, one month, then I went to Tanna.

txGroup.tx: Tatsman pak Tanna. Apan pato Tanna, ntau inru, go atlag ilates.

idGroup.fg: Attachment to Tanna. I went to Tanna, for two years and six months.

txGroup.tx: Go amer tao Tanna mer mai pak Efil.

idGroup.fg: And I left Tanna and came back to Vila.

txGroup.tx: Polis. Atutu panpanpan 1948 kin go apo lak Liaal. Ga ipo mat ntau ne, March.

idGroup.fg: Police. I stayed and then in 1948 I got married to Liaal. She was to die this year in March.

txGroup.tx: Ale uto Lamelis to, 1948 nen alak, me ato plisman lak.

idGroup.fg: We went to Lamelis, 1948 when I was married, I was a married policeman.
We stayed until 1949, 1950,
1952 until l955, then I was finished as a policeman.
I came back to the island.

txGroup.tx: Uto naur to panpanpan nlag iwat 1959. Nlagwat p̃ur.

idGroup.fg: We stayed on the island until the cyclone of 1959. A big cyclone.

txGroup.tx: Go umuf mai pak menlan. Mai to menlan to. Tototo panpanpan.

idGroup.fg: And we moved to the mainland. Came to the mainland. Stayed on.

txGroup.tx: Ale rumer wou apan lekor skul etan sanie. Alekor pablik skul etan sanie,

idGroup.fg: And they told me to go and run the school there. I ran the public school down there

txGroup.tx: ntau ilaru apan, me 1973 to pan 1980 malen ruindipenden, ale komam unom.

idGroup.fg: for seven years, 1973 to 1980, time of Independence, then we finished.

txGroup.tx: Nlaken iwelkia Franis kipeto muf ale komam unom mai pak elag sa,

idGroup.fg: Because the French were leaving so we finished and came back up here,

txGroup.tx: mer lekor Sante skul esa. Nafet tija plak Sante skul,

idGroup.fg: to run the Sunday School. All the teachers at the Sunday School,

txGroup.tx: amer lekor wer ntau ilaru, nen amer lekor teesa skul esa.

idGroup.fg: I looked after them for seven years and the children at the school here.

txGroup.tx: Go api tija ni devosen, tija ni devosen ato mal mai.

idGroup.fg: And I am the teacher of devotion, from then.

txGroup.tx: Iofa ntau ralim inru, kin ato moning devosen.

idGroup.fg: Over twenty years I did morning devotion.
I stayed until nineteen,

txGroup.tx: ntau pei nen pa, 1994. Ruling elda imer mai lek wou na,

idGroup.fg: las year, 1994. The ruling elder came and said to me,
"Take some of his work.
I'll rest because we have too many young people."

txGroup.tx: Malfanen tefsofus rusel nam̃le kit. Neu kato me askot mus nafte weswes ki.

idGroup.fg: Now the young people are taking their place. I will stay and support the work you do.

txGroup.tx: Askot mus. Kin ato esum̃ to. Tototo panpanpaan go olfala neu ki np̃aun ita leg mau.

idGroup.fg: I am with you. I will stay at home. I stayed until my wife went a little bad in the head.

txGroup.tx: Ale rato esum̃ ntau inru rata pak tenaor mau. Rato esum̃ to, ato lekor nmatu neu nlaken np̃aun ita leg mau.

idGroup.fg: We stayed in the house for two years, we didn't go any place. We both stayed at home, I cared for my wife because she wasn't well.

txGroup.tx: Ito esum̃ to, ipi tenen ito fam m̃as. Aga preg nafnag kefam. Panpanpan ntau ne.

idGroup.fg: She stayed at home, she only ate. I made her food to eat. Until this year.

txGroup.tx: Maj namba faef go ipo tm̃alu. Rato esum̃ ntau iskei ntau inru.

idGroup.fg: Until the fifth of March when she died. We stayed at home for one or two years.

txGroup.tx: Kin ga kipe mat ga, me neu kin kaipe kano kaipe pi tiawi, kaipe kano pak talm̃at.

idGroup.fg: She died, but I am old, I can't work in the garden.

txGroup.tx: Ato lek nawesien me kaipe kano weswes. Nlaken nafitiawian totur namsaki nlaken neu me apo to su marom̃it.

idGroup.fg: I see work (that needs to be done), but I can't work anymore. Because of sickeness I have got old, because I have asthma.

txGroup.tx: Asmok teetwei me mai mai pak malen ato lekor skul etan. 1977

idGroup.fg: I smoked long ago then I ran the school down there. In 1977

txGroup.tx: apak hospitel pa go dokta itp̃okor wou sikaret. 1977 mai pak mees atap smok mau.

idGroup.fg: I went to hospital and the doctor banned me from smoking. From 1977 to today I haven't smoked.

txGroup.tx: Ale naminwen kineu api natam̃ol iskei nen amin.

idGroup.fg: Drink, I am a man who can drink.

txGroup.tx: Oh, natam̃ol itik nen itol neu naminwen.

idGroup.fg: There is no man who can beat me drinking.

txGroup.tx: Malen ap̃elgat botel tefla alaokin nkanrok, anpaki botel.

idGroup.fg: When I open a bottle, I stand it up in my mouth and I throw it away.

txGroup.tx: Nmalok ato mingi, me atli reki alkol nrak pei.

idGroup.fg: I drink kava, but I'm telling you about alcohol in those days.

txGroup.tx: Nrak pei ga naat ita tol kineu naminwen mau. Amin me asmok, paket inru naliati iskei.

idGroup.fg: In those days there wasn't a man who could beat me. I drank and I smoked, two packets a day.

txGroup.tx: Me malen amin, paket itol. Me 1977 dokta ina, "P̃ata smok mau."

idGroup.fg: But when I drank, three packets. But in 1977 the doctor said, "Don't smoke anymore".

txGroup.tx: Go atao sikaret. Me nmarok, itapi tenen kin ata tae naftekin ipreg marom̃it mau.

idGroup.fg: And I gave up cigarettes. But my breathing, I don't know why I have got asthma.

txGroup.tx: Ilakor pi sikaret, ilakor pi nai, me nrak pei ata sua mau. Me nrak pei ata su marom̃it mau.

idGroup.fg: It could be cigarettes, it could be alcohol, but before I never had asthma. But that time I hadn't caught asthma.

txGroup.tx: Me mees ne, naliati iskei, kafo mas sol mersin,

idGroup.fg: But today I have to take medecine,

txGroup.tx: mersin ni marom̃it. Ipiatlaken itu, atu panpan malen anrogo iwelkia ato pam,

idGroup.fg: asthma medecine. I have some, and when I feel I am starting to pump,

txGroup.tx: kaimer pan wesi iskei. Amingi kaimer tu.

idGroup.fg: I go and take it, I drink it down.

txGroup.tx: Sprei, rutraem nrik wou kin me amalki.

idGroup.fg: They tried to get me to use spray, but I didn't want to.

txGroup.tx: Nlaken sprei ipi tenen kupilo p̃ulp̃og. Kefei pak paket. Me tetenrak apak talm̃at pa me ametp̃akro ito.

idGroup.fg: Because this spray you take when you wake in the morning. It goes in your pocket. But sometimes I go to the garden but I forget it is there.

txGroup.tx: Malen ipaakor ki wou talm̃at, ipi malwan apato talm̃at to.

idGroup.fg: Then it comes on me at the garden, it is the time I am at the garden.

txGroup.tx: Dokta ipo nrik wou ki sprei. Ipo tao ki.

idGroup.fg: The doctor told me to use a spray. He gave it to me.

txGroup.tx: Amai atu tiawi neu ki. Tiawi neu iskei ipato sanpe. Kalon. Harry Kalon. Atuaki.

idGroup.fg: I came and gave it to my father. My father who stays over there. Harry Kalon. I gave it to him.

txGroup.tx: Ale kalo Meibel imai, ga. Anrik Meibel ki, "Apiatlak sprei inru, me amal to iuski.

idGroup.fg: Then Mabel came. I said to Mabel. "I've got two sprays, but I don't want to use them.

txGroup.tx: Nlaken kafak talm̃at tenrak, ametp̃akro me apato talm̃at tu me ipaakor ki wou go amat talm̃at."

idGroup.fg: Because I go to the garden sometimes, I forget it and I am at the garden and I could have an asthma attack and die at the garden."

txGroup.tx: Me taplet iwi. P̃̃ulp̃og asol taplet atae pak sap, sap ko sap apa.

idGroup.fg: But the tablets are good. I take one in the morning and I can go any place.

txGroup.tx: Malen aler mai kotfan welkia anrogo astat pam ale wan taplet.

idGroup.fg: When I come back in the afternoon, and I feel it start, I take a tablet.

txGroup.tx: Ipi nam̃olien neu nen atu wes tu mees.

idGroup.fg: That is my life as I am today.

itmGroup.ti: A story about the Second World War

txGroup.tx: O, rulaap, esa rutalaap mau, me Esanr. [edited] Go mal ni nafkal nam̃er ni America rulaap, esa rutalaap mau, me Esanr. [/edited]

idGroup.fg: Oh there were many, not here, but in Santo. [edited] At the time of the war, there were lots of Americans, not here, but in Santo.[/edited]

txGroup.tx: Nam̃er got me nam̃er taar. Navy, Army nametrau nam̃er fserser.

idGroup.fg: Black men and white men. Army and navy, all different men.

txGroup.tx: Rupo piatlak nmatu gar nen rumai. Nmatu gar nen rumai, rutkal faef handred.

idGroup.fg: They had their women who came too. They had 500 women with them.

txGroup.tx: Me nmatu nen rupi nmatu ni nafet Ofisa. Rumai,

idGroup.fg: They were the officers' wives. They came

txGroup.tx: ruwi, rusemsem lek patlas natam̃ol. Me rutraif mai ko rufatlasik rumsagik.

idGroup.fg: they were good, they were happy to meet any man. They come driving or they meet you or they take you in the car.
You say, "Where are you going?", "Okay". With them for three months.

txGroup.tx: Rupi nam̃er wi. Nafisoklepwen gar itop. Kutae America,

idGroup.fg: They were good men. They were very rich. You know America,

txGroup.tx: runa kopan eksesaes, pak eksesaes pa. Runa kofan mees baseball, upak baseball pa.

idGroup.fg: they say to do exercises, we do exercises. They say we'll play baseball, we played baseball.
They say we'll go for a wander, we went for a wander.

txGroup.tx: Ko runa kopan min upa unomser of uniform upan min.

idGroup.fg: Or they say, we'll drink, we all wear uniforms and we go and drink.
