txGroup.tx: Rupanpan rutrau wi top ki wou, pan pan pan runa, "Wik nen tu tukfak Solomon. Kuta mtak mau". Ana,

idGroup.fg: They were good to me, then they said, "This week we'll go to the Solomons. Don't be scared." I said,

txGroup.tx: "Kaipe saen reki nmaten, ded, ded, laif, laif." Me kafman m̃as malen kin inrogo, go ipulu wou Suranta.

idGroup.fg: "I signed up for death, if I die, I'm dead, if I live, I'm alive." But the government heard and they pulled me out to go to Suranta.

txGroup.tx: Go ipiatlak natam̃ol rusot. Me ito psir me imal kin apa.

idGroup.fg: There was a shortage of men. But they were lying as they didn't want me to go (to the Solomons).

txGroup.tx: Afmer pa me afla lakor wel Jimmy Steven ko aflakor mat Solomon.

idGroup.fg: If I went, I would be like Jimmy Stevens (who went to the Solomons and came back alive), or I would be dead in the Solomons.

txGroup.tx: Ipi esuan nam̃olien neu. Kin mai kin itu san to. Pan pan pak mees ne, apitlak ntau 77.

idGroup.fg: That's my life. Until today when I am 77 years old.

itmGroup.ti: English police in Santo in the 1940s

txGroup.tx: Neu kin nawesien nen kin upatkos Esanr. Plisman upi ralim utiuti me apak Esanr pa Esanr ruta to sisi.

idGroup.fg: The work we did in Santo. We were ten police on duty, I went to Santo. On Santo they were still shooting.

txGroup.tx: 1941 me natam̃ol ruta to tmer sir. Nlaken komam utu Kanal,

idGroup.fg: In 1941 men were shooting each other there. That's why we stayed at Luganville,

txGroup.tx: reki nam̃er ni Sak Pei, me Pot Lori, me ruto of polet mai pak hospitel.

idGroup.fg: for people from Shark Bay and Port Lory would come in to hospital with bullet wounds.

txGroup.tx: Go komam upan malen kin man pus ruta to tmer sir, me ipi mal kerkerai.

idGroup.fg: And we went when the bush men were still shooting each other.

txGroup.tx: Malen kin utkos kin p̃amro ki, Totel Pei pak Sak Pei. Ipi em̃ae top,

idGroup.fg: It was a hard time, when we stayed there, think about Turtle Bay, to Shark Bay. It is a long way,

txGroup.tx: me malen ana kafa. Ana kawes natus pa. Runrik wou ki, "Malen p̃afa, p̃awalu sot ni plisman, p̃aweslu pulp̃ou,

idGroup.fg: but back then I wanted to go. I took a letter there. They told me, "When you go, take off your police shirt, take off your hat,

txGroup.tx: p̃aweslu polet, p̃afai nal. P̃akaro me p̃afa. "Nlaken ipitlak man pus nmaota ni Totel Pei pak Sak Pei. Ale apa.

idGroup.fg: take off your bullets and put them in your basket. You go without clothes." Because there are wild men between Turtle Bay and Shark Bay.

txGroup.tx: Rusi natam̃ol, rupam natam̃ol, pan pan pan pan pak Sak Pei pa.

idGroup.fg: They shoot men and eat men until you get to Shark Bay.

txGroup.tx: Malen kin apu ni Kulon nen to Kulon nen iplak Toumer to, Apu ga Kami. Kami Kulon.

idGroup.fg: This time when Kulon's grandfather was there, Kulon who married Toumer, Kami is his grandfather. Kami Kulon.

txGroup.tx: Malen ito Sak Pei. Go ina, "Boy, yu kam olsem wanem?" Nlaken ana panpan apak plantesen ga go apo of nkal.

idGroup.fg: Then he was at Shark Bay. And he said, " Boy, how did you get here?" Because I put my clothes on just when I got to his plantation.

txGroup.tx: "O me kuur naor nen to mai? Me ku, kutap piatlak trabol mau?" Ana, "Itik".

idGroup.fg: "Oh, did you follow along there to come? And didn't you have any trouble?" I said, "No."

txGroup.tx: Malen amai asrakor sot, asrakor pulp̃ou, asrakor strap, ale amai.

idGroup.fg: When I came I hid my shirt, I hid my hat, I hid my strap, then I came."

txGroup.tx: Ilek wou trau mur, me ina, "Yu laki." Ale pan patu p̃og go amatur, p̃ulp̃og go amer ler mai pak Kanal.

idGroup.fg: He looked at me and laughed, and said, "You're lucky." I stayed the night, slept and then came back to Kanal (Luganville).

txGroup.tx: Ipi em̃ae. Malen nafkal ito na kemai. Komam English plis uta matur mau.

idGroup.fg: It is a long way. Then the war was about to start. We English police didn't sleep at all.

txGroup.tx: Kanal pak Fenue, Fenue pak Kanal, p̃og go kusiwer. Me itapi napu ni natam̃ol taos napu ni loto mau.

idGroup.fg: Kanal to Fenue, Fenue to Kanal, at night, you walked. But it wasn't a man-made road like a car road.

txGroup.tx: Napu nen kupa kupu na serpal ni naniu. Nen p̃afan ke malik, p̃atpili lele kin.

idGroup.fg: On this road you must carry a coconut torch (the bract of the coconut tree that can be burned to use as a torch). When it is dark, you light it and you can see.

txGroup.tx: Pan pak Fenue pa. Plis man ni English. Upi teni nam̃er, nam̃er ni Erakor. Me rutu English.

idGroup.fg: Go to Fenue. The English police. We were from Erakor. But they were English.

txGroup.tx: Me rutatsman pak eFenue. Kunrogo rutu tm̃otum komai pak Kanal.

idGroup.fg: They were on attachment at Fenue. You hear they (the police) knock at the door. We came back to Kanal.

txGroup.tx: Mal ni nafkal. Ito pareki sa.

idGroup.fg: Time of the war. It came out here.
There is this snake and it would-.
It was up at Pufa [behind Montmartre] and it came. It came
the small islands that come right up to Eratap there.
And the two islands there, one which they call Kap̃um lep and the other is Kap̃um rik.
And these two islands, this snake wanted to split them.
There is the point at Eter, it is a long point, and this snake split it.
That's why it is short now. But the point at Etmat is a long one, the point at Etmat which is where we are now.
Etmat point. But the point at Emut and the point at Eter are there.
The point at Emut which is in line with the two islands there. Because its face, its face, that is this point at Emut.
Its face there. M̃aatleplep is the name of the snake. He's the one who split them into two small islands there.
They call them Kap̃um rik and Kap̃um lep. That's it.
The Erakor side I can talk about. But I can't talk about the Eratap side because it belongs to people from Erarap. OK.
I didn't go to school somewhere else, I just went to the village school.
My education was just at the village school.
Started my work. In my life, I didn't go somewhere else to work.
And I worked with old people, the village, the community.
I looked after my old people until some died, I kept looking after the others,
those who were my family who were old. I looked after them until they died.
I looked after many sick people, in the clinic, like a hospital.
I was there, at the hospital for three years, I worked with the sisters and nurses.
In the hospital (NT) Until? (KK) PMH (NT) How many years? (KK) Three years.
(NT) Three years, nineteen...? (KK) 1949.
1960, 1961. When the sea flooded the island
I was at the hospital, and I looked after the sick, when Uma was damaging the hospital.
I moved the sick people inside, made them go to a safe place.
And my next job when I left the hospital.
I crossed back to the village. I came back to the village. (That means the same thing twice, eh?).
I came back to the village, I stayed there a while, then I worked for the electricity company.
I looked after the the generator night and day.
I was there for nine years.
After nine years I got sick because of the diesel.
All that made too much gas inside my body.
I left and some heavy work that weakened me made me leave the job.
But my first work, my attempt at another job was at the hospital as a carpenter.
I worked with some carpenters who had come from Australia. That's where I made a mistake.
There was one carpenter when I was with them, he was called Laurie,
Lex, and David, a, Buckingham and who else, I forget.
And the last one came back to visit me the first month after they left here.
Mr.Waily, who made the school that is in the village. That is there today.
I was with him, that's how I learned about working.
So that I know how to make my own house,
know how to be a carpenter. 'Mtakseu' is the custom name for a carpenter.
And when I could do this, I went back to work at the electricity company.
While I finished there, I came back, because I got sick and had to stay home.
I was at home and looked after all the old people, many old people who were my old people, I looked after them.
I helped them. (NT) You worked in the garden? (KK) Garden...
And whatever they wanted me to do, I would do for them.

itmGroup.ti: Faat inru—the two stones at Ekasufat Rik

idGroup.fg: There are two stones
at Ekasufat rik. They talked to each other, these rocks,
and they said to each other that they wanted to be at the sea.
And the small stone said to the big stone, "You go first.
I will come behind."
And they ended up arguing with each other
until the the big rock said to the small one,
"You go first down there, I will meet you, we will go in the ocean,
that people paddle out to, we will be in the middle.
Now they had an argument.
The small rock told the big rock, "You go first and I will follow."
And the big rock said, "You are small, but I am big.
When you go first, I'll follow and I'll meet you and we will go."
They kept arguing. Until the small rock said, "Alright, I will go first."
And the small stone stayed up high, it rolled down.
The big rock wanted to come, it couldn't meet him.
And they are still there until today.
It is only a short story.
The old people who stayed at Em̃eltefra before.
There were many people there.
They were many, and there were a lot of bad things.
So the chief of Em̃eltefra expelled all the troublemakers.
They are the ones who went to Etago.
Yes, those that were there, they scattered.
They came to Erfat, they came to Em̃elsa, to the place they call Erakor.

txGroup.tx: Orait. Rutkos, rumer nrus mai pak Ekasufat.
txGroup.mr: Orait ru= to wes ru= mer nrus mai pak Ekasufat
txGroup.mg: alright:BI 3P.RS= stay there 3P.RS= again move come to p.name

idGroup.fg: Alright. They were there, they came across to Ekasufat.
To stay at Ekasufat. When prayer (Christianity) came.
When Christianity came the people were in the light and then they came.
And the Ekasufat chief died, the chief who they called Nmak.
He died and then there was a man who would take the people back.
That man was called Fakalomara, he was from Samoa.
He came with them, they wanted to come, they made the village by the beach at Egis.
And, at that time, as many people came, they were dying.
There was a sickness, the sickness was dysentery.
They died and died until a few went across to the small island.
They were at the small island and their numbers started to pick up and grow until this generation.
And we would be born there and we would leave the island and come here.
We would make this place a village.
Yes, when we left the small island and came in 1959.
As the wind began to hit it made us come over to Efate.
And we would make this place Erakor village.

itmGroup.ti: Mantu the flying fox and Erromango

idGroup.fg: The story of the flying fox, I will tell about the flying fox that is there.
Yes the flying fox that was at Rentapau long ago, it went to Erromango.
It was there until it wanted to go to Erromango, to go back to Erromango, and one day it went.
And it had this egg, but
that flying fox, it came, it layed an egg,
two eggs, it layed two eggs.
And those two eggs stayed at Erromango.
And people from Erromango wanted to hit him.
And he said, "I will leave you the eggs. You will look after them and I will return to Efate."
And today he came to Efate.
And that flying fox is still at the place they call Ewor today.
Asaraf, he is a man from long ago.
We have heard our grandfather and grandmother tell us that he was tall, really tall.
When he wanted to go, he was there and he wanted to go to Erromango.
When he crossed the sea to Erromango, the sea came to his knee.
Here (indicating his chest) wasn't wet.
He went to Erromango and he came back, and one day, well, Erromango it was-, you could be on Efate and you could see Erromango.
Just close.
But the one from Erromango, [correction] the one from Efate made him angry.
And he went to Erromango, he went, and, well, he put his head into the water like this.
He did that with (his head) and the sea rose.
Well, he put his head in the water and he twisted his head like this so that the water rose.
And then you couldn't see Erromango.
And now that he stayed there, he stayed on Efate until the time that he died, and the old people of that place buried him.
But because he was so tall, they bent him in three.
The story of Mumu and Kotkot, it is not an empty story, it is a story that is still alive.
So Mumu and Kotkot used to walk around Vanuatu.
To Banks and then back to Aneityum, they would walk like that.
But the places they stopped at were Tongoa and Emae.
They are their islands.
And everytime they have their road that goes along there.
They always have their road along here, it goes straight.
It goes along the saltwater, to Erromango, Tanna, Aneityum. Then it comes back.
And they stay there, they look to see if
anyone is behaving badly and they go and hit him.
Sometimes they punish someone,
they make someone sick. But they make them get well again.
But sometimes they make them die.
They will be dead. And many times they appear to people.

itmGroup.ti: Natopu ni Erakor—the spirit who lives at Erakor

idGroup.fg: The natopu (local spirit) that lives here, it is our natopu.
Everyone from Erakor is scared of the natopu which they call 'maarik' (mister).
When you do something wrong,
Maarik will give you a small punishment, like he makes you sick.
But there are people who will then give you leaf medecine to drink, and you will become healthy again.
People here have leaf medecine for 'maarik'.
And 'maarik', long ago, when, in the time of darkness, they were there, they were a group, they were warriors.
Many warriors, they had battles with the warriors from Eratap, from Pango, from Mele.
As they were there, you know maarik changed into a person who was a healer. He was a healer.
'Kulru' means a kleva (the Bislama term for a healer).
Yes, that man is a kleva, so that if something were to happen, he would have told all the people about it.
When they were there, then Christianity was about to come.
And he said to all the people, "There is something. It will come. It will be a good thing.
And you will all go to this thing that will come, you will all go to it.
But I will stay inside custom for you. Until today." And he is the 'maarik' who is still there.
I want to tell you all this small story
The story is about Mister Taap̃es.
Taap̃es is a bird which, many times we say damages our bananas.
You plant bananas, taap̃es goes and eats them, but his wisdom is what I want to talk about.
One day he called many birds to one place. "I want to talk with you because
we are birds. But why does the hawk hurt us, it eats us?
Some days he stays away. He sees us here. He comes and hurts us.
But we are a group."
He said to them, "I want us to come together to cut a canoe."
And all the birds said, "How will we cut it?" "I will show you how we cut a canoe."
And they came together in one place and he said they would cut a canoe. They cut the canoe. They got the wood, the wood would be 'nel' wood.
They went and arranged it so they could be in one place. And they hit
they chopped the tree, their 'nel' tree.
They hit it a second, third, fourth time. They worked it until
it looked like a boat, it floated. But he said, "This is the time for us to come together.
Many birds came: flying fox, owl,
and tap̃es. He was the chief. All the birds came to stay at one place.
And he said, "I want to tell you we should cry out". The pigeon cooed,
the rooster crowed, each of the birds did their work as they knew how, the flying fox cried.
Then they went to the boat and he said, "Now we'll stay here."
Every animal called out at the top of its voice. But you look, the hawk started for
the hill. He left the hill and came. You see, truly. Then he came, flying around us until he finished. He flew off a long way. Then he came back,
he wanted to pinch us like that. And you scattered.
But he would come and stick his fingers in the middle of the bananas and go.
And it is your time now, our time to cover him, to kill him.
They heard him and stayed there. They called, the pidgeon shouted, but he cooed.
Each bird followed its habit.
The rooster crowed and the hawk left the hill. "Eh, here he comes."
They were there until he came down, came and put his fingers like he should.
He would show them his claws (to scare them) as if to show them how he would grab one and eat it.
then he went a long way, then he came back. And taap̃es said to them,
"As he comes now he will grab some. Then, you look, he will stick his fingers on top like this,
then he will come down, down, down. And we'll go our different ways, but he will put his fingers in the banana."
And it is their time (for revenge), they kill him. They watched and the hawk flew down around them until he finished and flew a long way away
then he looked like he was going to fly but his fingers were ready.
Then he came close to grab some of them, and they scattered.
But his claws stuck in the banana. He tried to get out but he couldn't because the banana is soft,
that's the boat he chose. He got wise.
As he put his claws into the banana he tried to fly away, but he couldn't.
And it is the hawk that they covered, they cut him (and bit him) but the flying fox bit him. But every bird covered him and
his life was finished, he died.
And that is where this small story ends.
Yes, about the time of the old people.
At that time, the village of Erakor, Efate, was seven villages.
One was called Em̃eltafra.
This one is called Em̃elsa. This one is called Emlaliu.
This one is called Ekasufat.
This one is called Em̃lasei. Etmat is the sixth.
There are six villages.
But the place they call the main village is called Ekasufat.
The head chief is there. And when Christianity came,
that's what the story says, Christianity came. Those from Ifira came, from Pango, from Eratap.
We did it, spoiled the food that they would abandon for Christianity.
They came with all the weapons, spears and so on. Those who were looking after these things didn't go to their gardens.
And all the grandparents were eating wild arrowroot.
When you eat namkanr, it stings your mouth, but the old people were strong and ate it.
This is not good food at all, but they didn't have other things to eat.
They ate it, it stung their mouth, they swallowed it, and it stung their bellies. They shat it out and it made them numb.
But they were strong for it. Until the time when the brown missionaries came here.
And they gave them Ekasufat. And when they left Ekasufat,
they came to Egis, here.
The place where the school is now. But they got dysentery and they shat blood.
And the people were dying day and night.
Until some that were there went across (to the island).
My father was one of them. He was a boy but they took him across to Erakor.
And when they went to Erakor it was bush. And they went and they would clear the island so that they could build houses
which they went to live in. Until my father would marry in 1918
and we would be born on Erakor island.

txGroup.tx: Taos me ni lakun tiawi teetwei ruto san kin Franis Roman Catholic itkos.

idGroup.fg: As for the lagoon, the old people before stayed up at the place where the French Roman Catholics were.

txGroup.tx: Franis Roman Catholic rusosoki Momat. Me nafsan matu ni tiawi rusosoki Epkat.

idGroup.fg: The French Roman Catholic place, they call Montmartre. But its real name, what our ancestors called it, is Epkat.

txGroup.tx: Kaaru nen ito rumer sosoki Epak. Epak kin po pak Ep̃uf.

idGroup.fg: Another place there they call Epak. From Epak you go to Ep̃uf.

txGroup.tx: Me teetwei mal nen tiawi rutu, ag kukano pak esanie.

idGroup.fg: But in those days, olden days, you couldn't go to that place.

txGroup.tx: Kafan kopei pemisen na kofo pa. Kanrik naot kin me ifwel kin afkop namurien neu pan rukfo wat kineu,

idGroup.fg: I would go and ask permission to go there. I would talk with the chief, but if I just followed my own way, they would kill me,

txGroup.tx: rukfo pam kineu. Nlaken atap ptuki nafsan.

idGroup.fg: and eat me. Because I didn't talk to them.

txGroup.tx: Go malen kin rutu sanie, ipiatlak lak itol.

idGroup.fg: And while they were there, there were three wells.

txGroup.tx: Lak iskei rusoso ki lak Mpakur, ga kin lakun nen ipo mai pak esa.

idGroup.fg: The first well was called Mpakur, it is the one the lagoon came from.

txGroup.tx: Lak kaaru rusoso ki Ewotas, ito saot is Efat.

idGroup.fg: The second well was called Ewotas, at south-east Efate.

txGroup.tx: Lak katol ga ito Ep̃uf rusoso ki M̃autul me Mautfer.

idGroup.fg: The third well was at Ep̃uf and they called it M̃autul and Mautfer.

txGroup.tx: Me malen kin tenen ito esanie nam̃er nen ruto Ep̃uf rumur kapu.

idGroup.fg: But then, they were there, the people from Ep̃uf wanted laplap.

txGroup.tx: Malnen rumur kapu go ruto gar preg kapu.

idGroup.fg: Then they wanted laplap and they started to make laplap for them.

txGroup.tx: Me ser nrak nen kin rufreg kapu rupus altuk,

idGroup.fg: But every time they they made laplap they put island cabbage,

txGroup.tx: rupus sernale teflan me ati iskei nen rusosoki Katapel. Ga ipi ati nen ipiatlak faat iskei ito mai nrea.

idGroup.fg: and other things in it, but one grandmother, called Katapel. She is a grandmother who had a stone which she would come and turn.

txGroup.tx: Malnen inrea tefla. Kimer sel kai. Isel kai nen ito pregi kapu.

idGroup.fg: She would turn it. She took shellfish. She took shellfish and she made laplap.

txGroup.tx: Go, malnen ipak nana pa. Me selwan kin rupan teflan kin lak tol ne, runomser pi ntas.

idGroup.fg: Then she went. But when she wanted to do this for the three wells, they were all saltwater.

txGroup.tx: Go malen kin iku kia, ipreg nana ipa. Go ati me apu nen rutu elag Ep̃uf rupam ni ntas ne, runrogwiki.

idGroup.fg: She took the food and went. And the grandparents they were at Ep̃uf, they ate from the saltwater and they felt good.

txGroup.tx: Go teetwei gar ruta pakot ki mani, go ruta pakot ki tete namrun p̃et mau. Gar mĩit mas kinruto ptuki,

idGroup.fg: In those days they didn't buy things with money, and they didn't buy different things at all. They gave mats only,

txGroup.tx: go nawi, nap̃rai. Go ati nen ser nrak nen kin rupa, ga ito sol nafnag itop tol siluer.

idGroup.fg: and yam, sugar cane. And this grandmother, every time they went, she got more food than anyone else.
Because she put meat on the laplap.

txGroup.tx: Kai kapu ga ne, go runa, "Me ag kupreg kapu gaag ikakas wi nlaken kin kusati ntas."

idGroup.fg: Shellfish laplap,and they said, "You make a sweet laplap because you get it from the sea."

txGroup.tx: Rupan pan pan rumaetki nlaken kin sernale nen kin kefan kimer sel nawi laap.

idGroup.fg: Until they got angry with her because every time she went she got lots of yam.

txGroup.tx: Isat nap̃rai laap, esum̃ ga ip̃ur mau ki nafnag.

idGroup.fg: She got lots of sugarcane, her house was full of food.
This grandmother called Katapel.

txGroup.tx: Pan go rutmer nrikir ki, "E, tufo leperkat naftekin ito slati elau."

idGroup.fg: Then they said to themselves, "We should go and watch her taking things from the sea."

txGroup.tx: Malnen kin rumai nen ruuut ntas nen rukfo pregi kefak naniu nen runroi kapu.

idGroup.fg: Then they came to get saltwater to put with the coconut to milk the laplap.
And he, um.

txGroup.tx: Ga kefo inrok. Inrok ser nrak.

idGroup.fg: And she came after. She came last every time.

txGroup.tx: Malen kin ipo na imai tefla me ruipe preg naturiai iskei, kipe mai torakin to.

idGroup.fg: When she came back, they made one young man go and wait for her.

txGroup.tx: Malen kin ileka inre faat tefla, ipai kai pan pan inom tefla, naal na ipueti go iut ntas nen kefo pan nroi kapu ga.

idGroup.fg: Then he saw her turn the stone and fill up the basket with shellfish and take it and then pour seawater to milk her laplap.

txGroup.tx: Me malnen kin ipo na ipreg ga, naftekia, nana, teflan inom na itao,

idGroup.fg: But when she got all the, whatsit, and she left,

txGroup.tx: go isiwer sak ki ntaf pak elag, malen ipan pan pan pak elag ntaf go inrog nai iser.

idGroup.fg: and walked up the hill to the top, when she was high up the hill then she heard water flowing.

txGroup.tx: Malnen kin inrog nai iser teflan itarp̃ek ki napor naal ga ipato me itrau fit.

idGroup.fg: When she heard the water flowing, she dropped her basket and just ran.

txGroup.tx: Malnen kin ifit mai mai mai mai legki san kia Korman me pak etan,

idGroup.fg: Then she ran and ran and came to where Korman stadium is, but down,

txGroup.tx: ipu tefla nagis nranru nen kin kepnut nai keta ser mau.

idGroup.fg: and she pulled the two points of land to try and stop the water from flowing.

txGroup.tx: Ifit mai pak san, nai iskatur wes, mer fit mai mai pak san rusosoki Elaknap̃kas mer pueti me nai.

idGroup.fg: She ran to the place where the water was flowing through, to the place they call Elaknap̃kas, to pull the water.

txGroup.tx: Imer fit mai pak nagis esanie nen rusosoki Emetp̃er go Efatp̃osfiu.

idGroup.fg: She ran to this point which is called Emetp̃er and Efatp̃osfiu.

txGroup.tx: Malnen kin ientan tefla nen ke enkor ntas, ntas iskatur natuen.

idGroup.fg: When she lay down to block the saltwater, it went through her legs.

txGroup.tx: Malen ntas iskatur natuen tefla, faat nra nen kin.

idGroup.fg: Then the water flowed through her legs, they became two stones.

txGroup.tx: Iskatur natuen tefla, faat nra nen kin ratu. Iskatur natuen tefla gar ipi nra tu kaaru kin imakot mal ni Uma.

idGroup.fg: It flowed through her legs, these two stones are still there. It flowed through her legs like that, they are two, one was broken during (cyclone) Uma.

txGroup.tx: Me kaaru ita tu pan mees. Rusosoki Efatposfiu.

idGroup.fg: But the other one is still there today. They call it Efatposfiu.

txGroup.tx: Go naor Erakor teetwei ga itik.

idGroup.fg: And Erakor island was not there in the olden days.

txGroup.tx: Me malnen Katapel ientan teflan kin nai kin, me ntas ipo satktofi ipi naor.

idGroup.fg: But when Katapel lay down to block the water, it broke off the island.

txGroup.tx: Go malen kin ifit teflan mai mai imat. Ga kin itap̃o pato nametp̃agon nagis ne rusosoki Katapel. Nagis ni Katapel.

idGroup.fg: And when she ran like this, she died. She fell over at the point which is called Katapel. Katapel point.

txGroup.tx: Go malen ip̃o, ser nafaswen nen gar kin runomser pi faat lfek naur to.

idGroup.fg: And when she was rotten, each of the places she pushed at became stones around the island.

txGroup.tx: Go ipi nametp̃ag natrauswen ni Katapel.

idGroup.fg: And that is the end of the story of Katapel.

itmGroup.ti: Waia Tenene, a story of his life

txGroup.tx: Ore kineu, apaakor Erakor, naur ses, 1916.

idGroup.fg: Yes, I was born on the small island of Erakor in 1916.

txGroup.tx: ajoin a, British police, 1937 afinis, go,

idGroup.fg: I joined the British Police, and finished in 1937, and,

txGroup.tx: join Amerika 1942 weswes skot Amerika armi.

idGroup.fg: I joined the Americans and worked with the American army in 1942.
We were in a boat owned by BP (Burns Phelp).

txGroup.tx: Umos masin gan p̃ur inru lp̃eki kaaru Emos, ulp̃eki kaaru Maniur, uler mai.

idGroup.fg: We took two big machine guns and went around Moso and Maniuro, then came back.
Then we went into the bush with the army.
We made camp in the middle of Efate,

txGroup.tx: upuet telefon waia pak Forari. Go imai pak Efil.

idGroup.fg: we put up a telephone wire to Forari. And it came to Vila.
1946, then the war finished.
1948 I joined the French police.
I was in the French police until 1955, 1956.

txGroup.tx: Go afines mai pak natkon Erakor.

idGroup.fg: And I finished and came back to Erakor village.

txGroup.tx: Go api polis ni naot Charlie Kalmet.

idGroup.fg: And I was Chief Charlie Kalmet's policeman.

txGroup.tx: Malnen 1959. Malnen nlag iwat utm̃alu naur sees mai pak Efat. 1959, 1960.

idGroup.fg: In 1959, the cyclone hit the small island, and we came back to Efate, 1959, 1960.

txGroup.tx: Malnen umai pak natkon faum Erakor, Efat.

idGroup.fg: Then we came to the new village, Erakor, on Efate.

txGroup.tx: Go Charlie ipregi api polis ga ni natkon.

idGroup.fg: And Charlie made me his policeman in the village.
1960, 1960 I was a policeman until 1967.

txGroup.tx: Amer 1967 api polis me 1968 api kaonsel ga.

idGroup.fg: In 1967 I was a policeman, but in 1968 I was on the chief's council.

txGroup.tx: 68, 69, 70 go api naot aslat nawesien nig Charlie.

idGroup.fg: 1968, 69, 70 and I was the chief, I got Charlie's job.
I got his job until today 1998.
I am the chief of Erakor
Ah, those people from Mare (in New Caledonia) who came here long ago in the time of the Colonial Government.
The French government sent them to come as police.
They came to be police on Efate. On the side of the French, the French government.
There was fighting on Malakula, and it sent them to Malakula.
Fight with the people from Malakula.
And me, well, my father. My straight father, his brother, they shot him.
Those from Mare that came, those from Caledonia came here because the French government called them. A group of police came, they came here.
Okay, they went to fight with those from Malakula when there was a civil war.
And me, as my father's brother came from there. And they went to Malakula and they shot him. He was killed in Malakula.
They called him Nano. My father was a nurse at the big hospital in Noumea.
He went on leave and they sent him to France.
He went on the boat of the Messageries Maritimes. The ship. It went around to France and he came back here.
Then he got his job as a maître d'hôtel. So they sent him ashore.
He wanted to come ashore, he came, then those that were there became police. They were here and he joined them.
My father, Tenene. He stayed until he was married, then he stayed here.
He married my mother and he stayed here.
They had land that the chief of Ifira gave them at Emlap̃o, where Kawenu (college) is.
Those from Mare stayed there, those from Caledonia. When they married, they came to Erakor. And they moved here.

itmGroup.ti: Timteo Kalmet, a story about his life

idGroup.fg: My name is Timteo Kalmet.

txGroup.tx: Api teesa ni Charley Kalmet go Pali.

idGroup.fg: My parents are Charley Kalmet and Pali.
I was born on February 25th, 1954.
My clan is the yam,
they call it mleo, the mleo clan.

txGroup.tx: Mleo miel nlaken ipiatlak mleo inru, mleo tar go mleo miel.

idGroup.fg: Red mleo because there are two mleo, the white and the red one.
And I am of the mleo clan.

txGroup.tx: Go kineu apak skul 1961 naur sees.

idGroup.fg: I went to school on the small island.
I was born in 1954, and I'd start school in 1961.
(NT) You were born on the small island?
(TK) The small island.

txGroup.tx: Kin askul malpei, upei skul vilej skul malpei kin kindi.

idGroup.fg: That's where I went to school first, we went to the village school, first to kindy.

txGroup.tx: Kindergarten ntau iskei ko inru m̃as,

idGroup.fg: I was at kindergarten for just a year or two,
that was 1958 and 59,

txGroup.tx: go Wabaiat kin ipi tija nigmam,

idGroup.fg: and Wabaiat was our teacher,
and Kaltap̃au.

txGroup.tx: Ale English, [a]. Inom, malnen skul ni Esnaar,

idGroup.fg: English, eh? Finish, then the school at Esnaar,

txGroup.tx: rupregi istat. Go upak Franis skul,

idGroup.fg: was started. And we went to French school,

txGroup.tx: komam ulaap kin upak Franis skul, go astat 1961 kin askul Esnaar.

idGroup.fg: and many of us went to the French school, and I started at Esnaar in 1961.

txGroup.tx: Pan tkal 1963 go apas pak skul, Ecole

idGroup.fg: Until 1963 and I went to the school, Ecole
Communal in Port Vila.
I was there from 1964 until 1967.

txGroup.tx: 1968 go astat lycée, go ato lycée 1967 pan tkal 1973,

idGroup.fg: I started at the lycée in 1968 until 1973,

txGroup.tx: so skul neu itap, itap top mau.

idGroup.fg: my school life was not too long.
I didn't go to any university.

txGroup.tx: Me lycée askul fom wan, tu, tri.

idGroup.fg: I was at the lycée for form one, two, three.

txGroup.tx: Ale fom tri go apak ata kontiniu kin mau, me apak komesel school,

idGroup.fg: After form three I went to commercial school,
it was a technical school

txGroup.tx: nanre ni komes nanre ni taiping, akaonting go sekreterial wok.

idGroup.fg: to learn commerce, typing, accounting and secretarial work.
I finished school,

txGroup.tx: apo ta fines ki skul neu mau

idGroup.fg: I didn't finish school

txGroup.tx: nlaken ntau mlaap nen itu go apak Nume reki nen kin rukmas namtak.

idGroup.fg: because the last year I went to Noumea for them to cut out my eye.

txGroup.tx: Namet kineu isa, rukmas slatlua ito ptin.

idGroup.fg: My eye was bad, they had to cut it out because it hurt.
My eye was bad, 1963
an umbrella wire pierced it.

txGroup.tx: Me malne runa ruksentki kineu kafak Nume ko Australia

idGroup.fg: Then they wanted to send me to Noumea or Australia

txGroup.tx: reki nen rukfreg tenmatun me mama imal.

idGroup.fg: so that they could do something, but my mother didn't want it.

txGroup.tx: Mama neu imal, itli na inrom kineu go itli na kafei to.

idGroup.fg: My mother didn't want it, she said she loved me and she said I should stay first.

txGroup.tx: Go ato pan namtak kipe to taar pan pan istat ptin,

idGroup.fg: And I stayed until my eye was going white and started to hurt,

txGroup.tx: ipreg np̃auk kito ptin ser mal. 1972, namba tortin December

idGroup.fg: and gave me headaches all the time. In 1972, on the 13th December
I went to hospital in Noumea.

txGroup.tx: Doctor ijek ki kineu sa me apak hospitel Nume reki nen rukslatlua.

idGroup.fg: The doctor checked me here, but I went to hospital in Noumea so that they could take it out.

txGroup.tx: Ruslatlu tenen rupus met psir ne,

idGroup.fg: They took it out and put in this false eye,

txGroup.tx: me ata ta jenjkin mau tkal mees,

idGroup.fg: but I haven't changed it until today,

txGroup.tx: nlaken ruta nrik kineu ki gas kin kafo jenj kin mau.

idGroup.fg: because they didn't tell me when to change it.

txGroup.tx: Go malfane wik nentu namba 26 October go amer pak Nume nen rukleka,

idGroup.fg: And now, next week, on the 26th October I will go to Noumea for them to look at it,

txGroup.tx: nlaken kipe to muf ito pak elag kipe to sees.

idGroup.fg: because it has moved, it has moved up a little.
That's it.
1964 to 1973 I was at high school.
When I'm talking about I went to Noumea, 1972,
I went in 1972 and came back in March 1973.

txGroup.tx: Mer ler mai na kaskul. Me kaipe tapi intreski skul mau.

idGroup.fg: Came back to go to school. But I wasn't interested in school anymore.

txGroup.tx: Me ipi ntau mlaap neu ni komesel nen utae sat na natus neu ni teknikel skul.

idGroup.fg: It was my last year at commercial when I got my papers at the technical school.

txGroup.tx: Me kaipe ta mro wi kin na kafak skul mau. Atli na amur kaweswes.

idGroup.fg: I didn't want to go to school. I said I wanted to work.

txGroup.tx: Go apan weswes. Go kaipan weswes. Aweswes radio telekomiunikesen,

idGroup.fg: And I went to work. I worked in radio telecommunications
from 1973, 22 March 1973.

txGroup.tx: Ale apo risaen mal ntau ilakor pi ato 1973.

idGroup.fg: Then I resigned maybe it was 1973.
From the 22 March until 1979.

txGroup.tx: Go utransfe mai pak Et stesen, satelait, satelait, Et stesen pei

idGroup.fg: And we transferred to the first satellite Earth station
that was called Hebritel,

txGroup.tx: nen kin 1980 go rupo sosoki Vanitel,

idGroup.fg: that in 1980 would be Vanitel,
today it is Telecom.

txGroup.tx: So malen utransfe mai pak Hebritel,

idGroup.fg: Then we transferred to Hebritel,

txGroup.tx: go ato em̃rom, telegrafik rum go ato preg teleks, telegrafic, telefon,

idGroup.fg: and I was in the telegraphic room, doing telex, telegraph, telephone,

txGroup.tx: me rupam̃ori na awi nanre ni akaonting, nanre ni akaonting, go, administresen.

idGroup.fg: and they found that I had accounting and administration skills.

txGroup.tx: Go rupregi apak em̃rom, akaonting go administresen

idGroup.fg: And they took me in to accounting and administration
and I worked there until 1981,
when I resigned.

txGroup.tx: A risaen nlaken amur kames miusik.

idGroup.fg: I resigned because I wanted to play music.
Because then, 1963

txGroup.tx: sori 1961, kin astat intres ki miusik kin astat tkal miusik. Nlaken malen kin 1961 kin astat tkal miusik, gita me yukeleli.

idGroup.fg: sorry, 1961, I started being interested in music and started playing music. Because then, 1961, I started playing music, guitar and ukelele.

txGroup.tx: Gita me yuk, yukeleli. Even ipo piatlak akodien iskei ito esum̃.

idGroup.fg: Guitar and ukelele. There was even an accordion at home.

txGroup.tx: Kano ni Aneityum, Tanna iskei, ga imai to esum̃ nigmam to mal pei me ipitlak akodien iskei,

idGroup.fg: A man from Aneityum, from the south, he came and stayed at our home and he had an accordion.

txGroup.tx: Sori, ga ipiatlak banjo me akodien ne ga ipi teni gka neu kaaru, gka Tom, Tom Kalmet,

idGroup.fg: Sorry, he had a banjo but the accordion belonged to my other uncle Tom, Tom Kalmet,

txGroup.tx: brata ni gka neu, gka Charlie.

idGroup.fg: my father's brother, Charlie.

txGroup.tx: Ale ato ato mes ki akodien ne.

idGroup.fg: So I played this accordion.

txGroup.tx: Plak gita mana, me runrogo na ames wi,

idGroup.fg: With the guitar and so on, and they heard that I played well,
and sang a little.

txGroup.tx: Go stat miusik karie neu istat bild up esa.

idGroup.fg: And my music career built up from then.

txGroup.tx: Go 1981, malnen arisaen Vanitel apan mes.

idGroup.fg: And in 1981, then I resigned from Vanitel I went to play.

txGroup.tx: Apan weswes as resevesen maneje, Hotel Le Lagon.

idGroup.fg: I went to be the reservation manager at the Hotel Le Lagon.

txGroup.tx: Me kineu astat 1976 kin astat mes Hotel Le Lagon,

idGroup.fg: In 1976 I started at the Hotel Le Lagon,

txGroup.tx: me malpei kotkot ames naor laap.

idGroup.fg: but in those days I played at lots of places.

txGroup.tx: Me awelkin ato tae ki miusik neu skot nawesien ga,

idGroup.fg: I knew my music and its work,

txGroup.tx: aweswes Le Lagon aliat me p̃og go ames elag.

idGroup.fg: I worked at Le Lagon in the day and at night I played up above.

txGroup.tx: Taos 1968 ames nait klab rusosoki Tahitinui.

idGroup.fg: Like, in 1968 I played at the night club called Tahitinui.
Finished in 1973, I played at the Pandanus restaurant,
it finished in 1976 and I went back to Le Lagon.

txGroup.tx: Ale ato Le Lagon to ato mes esa.

idGroup.fg: Then I was at Le Lagon, I played there.
I worked at the radio.

txGroup.tx: Mai pak Vanitel mana, 1981, go arisaen Vanitel.

idGroup.fg: I came to Vanitel then I resigned in 1981.

txGroup.tx: Apan weswes Le Lagon as resevesen maneje.

idGroup.fg: I worked at Le Lagon as a reservation manager.

txGroup.tx: Me astil mentein ki nameswen neu, miusik pefomans,

idGroup.fg: But I kept up my playing, music performance,
until 1977, 1977 it was the Intercontinental Hotel.

txGroup.tx: Ipuetlu kineu sanie nlaken rumur asistan sels maneje, gar, hotel gar.

idGroup.fg: He took me there beccause they wanted an assistant sales manager at their hotel.

txGroup.tx: Apan weswes skotir, go mal skei mau ne

idGroup.fg: I went to work with them, and at the same time

txGroup.tx: go ruproposki kineu ki mane nen imer pak elag nanre ni miusik.

idGroup.fg: they offered me more money than I got for the music.

txGroup.tx: Go atao Le Lagon miusik go nawesien me ajoin Intercontinental.

idGroup.fg: And I left the music at Le Lagon and the work and I joined the Intercontinental.
And I was there for quite a while.

txGroup.tx: Pan tkal 1982 kin apato Hotel Le Lagon,

idGroup.fg: I stayed at Le Lagon until 1982,
I stayed at Le Lagon until 1982, then I left.
I stayed at the Intercontinental until 1984.
In 1984 I worked at the Sound Centre.

txGroup.tx: Rupuet kineu sanpen, ne rumur na kaweswes skotir.

idGroup.fg: They took me there to work with them.
I was a senior salesman.

txGroup.tx: Go malne go apo to demonstret ki sernale ni nameswen, taos piano, gita, elektronik sernale.

idGroup.fg: And I demonstrated how to use all the instruments, like piano, guitar and electronic things.

txGroup.tx: Pan go, ipiatlak group ni Papua New Guinea, West Papua iskei rumai pak sa, nagier Black Brothers,

idGroup.fg: Until there was a group from PNG, West Papua who came here, called Black Brothers,
they came in 1984 and 85.
They got me to play with them.

txGroup.tx: Ana ames skotir go ipiatlak janis nen, rusent ki kineu apak Papua New Guinea.

idGroup.fg: As soon as I played with them and there was this chance, and they sent me to Papua New Guinea.

txGroup.tx: Apan rikod ki kaset neu inru. Papua New Guinea inom,

idGroup.fg: I recorded my two cassettes. After Papua New Guinea,

txGroup.tx: aler mai, go ames skot Black Brothers BESA klab kin mees ipi Club Vanuatu.

idGroup.fg: I came back and played with the Black Brothers at the BESA club which today it is called Club Vanuatu.

txGroup.tx: Go ipi BESA klab malpei ipi, British ex-Servicemen's Association.

idGroup.fg: Before it was called the BESA club, British ex-Servicemen's Association.

txGroup.tx: Ale ames esan pan go ipiatlak tete p̃og kineu askei mes, taos wan man band.

idGroup.fg: So I played there and some nights I was solo, like a one-man-band.

txGroup.tx: Me tete p̃og ames skotir, taos, grup

idGroup.fg: Some nights I played with the group.

txGroup.tx: pan. Go manejmen ni Besa klab rutli na iwi na rukstop ki Black Brother

idGroup.fg: And the management of the Besa club said it would stop with the Black Brothers

txGroup.tx: me rukemploi ki kineu ful taem.

idGroup.fg: and employ me full time.

txGroup.tx: Gar nawesien gar. Nlaken ruleka na ijip.

idGroup.fg: That's their work. Because they saw it was cheap.

txGroup.tx: Go kineu askei me miusik ipiatlak veraeti,

idGroup.fg: And on my own I could play a variety of music,

txGroup.tx: nlaken alagki Bislama, Franis, English, go tete Spanish.

idGroup.fg: because I sing in Bislama, French, English and some Spanish.
So the Black Brothers were finished,

txGroup.tx: me kineu ato me ipo piatlak tete dispiut seserik. Black Brothers runrogtesa.

idGroup.fg: and I stayed, but they felt bad about it and we had a dispute. The Black Brothers felt bad.

txGroup.tx: Runrogtesa go rupregi ruto mai lek manejmen ni BESA klab.

idGroup.fg: They felt bad and they went to see the management of the BESA Club.
Until I left.

txGroup.tx: Malen atao go Intercontinental Hotel rumer puet kineu.

idGroup.fg: When I left, the Intercontinental Hotel took me back.
They kept me from 1985 until 1987.

txGroup.tx: Okay, ato 87, me Fairstar, ipiatlak p̃og iskei ipitlak imatur p̃og iskei nuof.

idGroup.fg: In 1987 the Fairstar was here overnight, they stayed at the wharf overnight.

txGroup.tx: Ale, nlaken ipitlak malne ilakor pi, ilakor pi Maj ko, ia, ore Maj ko Epril. Me ipitlak nlagwat iskei, go Fairstar imai, imatur p̃og, imtak ki nlagwat, go imatur p̃og.

idGroup.fg: It might have been March or April. There was a cyclone and the Fairstar stayed overnight, it was scared of the cyclone and it stayed overnight.

txGroup.tx: Me ipitlak anaonsmen ni saeklon, nlagwat iskei.

idGroup.fg: A cyclone was announced.

txGroup.tx: Go Fairstar imai, imatur p̃og, imtak ki nlagwat, go imatur p̃og.

idGroup.fg: And the Fairstar came and stayed overnight, it was scared of the cyclone so it stayed overnight.

txGroup.tx: P̃og krus daerekta go tete nam̃er nen rulekor raru na, Fairstar.

idGroup.fg: That night the cruise director and some of the crew of the Fairstar.

txGroup.tx: rumai min hotel, rumai sak to me ruto min hotel.

idGroup.fg: came to drink at the hotel.

txGroup.tx: Ruto nrog miusik, pan go runrogo iwi na, krus daerekta ga imai me ipaosi ki kineu,

idGroup.fg: They heard the music, they liked it and the cruise director came and asked for me,

txGroup.tx: "Me kumur p̃amai mes Fairstar?" Go ana, "O yes."

idGroup.fg: "Do you want to come and play of the Fairstar?" And I said, "Oh yes."

txGroup.tx: Ana, "Iwi me akam kofaos ki boss neu ni san."

idGroup.fg: I said, "Good, but you should talk to my boss here."

txGroup.tx: Go gar rupo paos ki boss neu ki.

idGroup.fg: They asked my boss about it.

txGroup.tx: Boss nen malne ipi jenral maneje, Oriliano Viniati.

idGroup.fg: My boss then was the general manager, Oriliano Viniati.

txGroup.tx: Ipi kano ni Italy. Rupaoskin go Mr. Viniati itli na,

idGroup.fg: He is Italian. They asked him and Mr. Viniati said,

txGroup.tx: "O itae neet mes, me kemer mai.

idGroup.fg: "He can go to you but he has to come back.

txGroup.tx: Keta pato Fairstar to mau, kemer mai."

idGroup.fg: He can't stay on the Fairstar, he has to come back."
They said, "Okay he will do two cruises."
And in 1987 I took two cruises,

txGroup.tx: krus 16 go af ni 17 ale rumai rumer lp̃eki kineu.

idGroup.fg: cruise 16 and half of 17 and they put me back here.

txGroup.tx: Go mal ne welkia ipregi repiutesen neu taos miusisen.

idGroup.fg: And that was how I built my reputation as a musician.

txGroup.tx: Ga imer pak elag tol nawesien nen atae pregi taos em̃rom administresen.

idGroup.fg: And it grew to more than I could do as I was inside the administration.

txGroup.tx: Go promosen neu welkia apak naurur apak naur ni Vanuatu.

idGroup.fg: To promote myself I went around the islands of Vanuatu.

txGroup.tx: Apan lag ipitlak Pentecost, Esanr, Emlakul, Epi, Tanna go tete naur seserik nen ruto ni Efat.

idGroup.fg: I went to sing to Pentecost, Santo, Malakula, Epi, Tanna and some islands around Efate.

txGroup.tx: Me 1987 go nametp̃agon ni krus neu na aler mai aweswes malses Intercontinental.

idGroup.fg: And in 1987 at the end of my cruise, I came back for a small while to the Intercontinental.
So Mary and I went to the Philippines.

txGroup.tx: Mtulep neu Mary ga iweswes Asian Development Bank.

idGroup.fg: My wife, Mary, works at the Asian Development Bank.

txGroup.tx: Go mal ne ga ipitlak nsaiseiwen ga ni sanpen.

idGroup.fg: At that time she had a meeting over there.

txGroup.tx: Me headquarters ni Asian Development Bank ito Filipins.

idGroup.fg: And the headquarters of the Asian Development Bank was in the Philippines.

txGroup.tx: Me mal ne apiatlak asel wi iskei,

idGroup.fg: At that time I had a good friend,

txGroup.tx: ga apiatlak fren wi iskei ga ipi, ga ga ipi nana alternate executive manager ni Asian Development Bank.

idGroup.fg: I had a good friend, he was the alternate executive manager of the Asian Development Bank.

txGroup.tx: Ito mai pak esan reki nen kin iset up ki Asian Development Bank ni sa.

idGroup.fg: He used to come here to set up the Asian Development Bank here.

txGroup.tx: Ga ipi teni Papua New Guinea. Nagien John Natera.

idGroup.fg: He was from Papua New Guinea. His name was John Natera.

txGroup.tx: John imai me ipi fren wi neu.

idGroup.fg: John was a good friend of mine.

txGroup.tx: Go itae na mtulep neu iweswes Asian Development Bank.

idGroup.fg: He knew that my wife worked for the Asian Development Bank.

txGroup.tx: Go itae na mtulep neu kefo pak Filipin nametp̃ag June ni 1987.

idGroup.fg: And he knew my wife would go to the Philippines at the end of June 1987.

txGroup.tx: Go ineu pakot pases. Ineu pakot tiket ni plen, me komam mtulep ranru pa.

idGroup.fg: He paid for my ticket and me and my wife both went.

txGroup.tx: Rana rapan go mtulep ga ito pak semina ga.

idGroup.fg: We went and my wife went to her seminar.

txGroup.tx: Ale kineu ato pak kos ni nalag.

idGroup.fg: And I went to a singing course.

txGroup.tx: Amur na kafreg na nalek kemer nrus wi.

idGroup.fg: I wanted to make my singing voice better.

txGroup.tx: Go ato pak kos sees neu, Yamaha Yupango ni Manila.

idGroup.fg: And I went to a short course at Yamaha Yupango in Manila.

txGroup.tx: Ale go ruto runrik kineu ki na,

idGroup.fg: And they said to me,

txGroup.tx: "Kuta nid nen p̃alearn ki nalem mau." Nlaken rupregi alag nalag itol.

idGroup.fg: "You don't need to improve your voice." Because they made me sing three songs.

txGroup.tx: Nalag iwelkia ihaf klasikel, "Don't cry for me Argentina."

idGroup.fg: A song that was half classical, "Don't cry for me Argentina."

txGroup.tx: Go tekaaru ipi "I just called to say I love you", go rok an rol iskei.

idGroup.fg: And the other was, "I just called to say I love you", and a rock and roll one.

txGroup.tx: Rujajki nalek me rupam̃ori na alag leg ki mal.

idGroup.fg: They judged my voice and they found that I sing in time.

txGroup.tx: Go apuet nmarok wi. Go aiuski diafram neu wi.

idGroup.fg: And I had good breath control, And I used my diaphragm well.
And my vocal chords were good.

txGroup.tx: Ale rutli na itap nid nen.

idGroup.fg: So they said that I didn't need it.

txGroup.tx: Ale me ato pan totan skot nam̃er nen ruto pan lenki piano.

idGroup.fg: So I went and sat with people learning the piano.

txGroup.tx: Go ato lek teflan ruto plei, me, ato pnakon, wel ki nlaken

idGroup.fg: I watched how they play and I copied it, well, because

txGroup.tx: ato leker m̃as ruto mes. Me ato leker me welkia amur katae teflan rumes.

idGroup.fg: I just watched them as they played. I watched them so that I could learn how they play.
And that is how I copied them.

txGroup.tx: Malen kin welkia ato pai m̃as.

idGroup.fg: As I was just filled up (my knowledge).

txGroup.tx: Inom, go m̃eltig nen rakfe ler.

idGroup.fg: Finish, and we were about to come back.
I went to the shop alone,

txGroup.tx: komam mal ilaap ga komam rato nru pak sto.

idGroup.fg: we had been to the shop together many times.

txGroup.tx: Me malne, aliat toknak iskei, me askei pak sto aliat.

idGroup.fg: But that time, Saturday, I went to the shop alone in the daytime.

txGroup.tx: Pan go rukidnap ki kineu sto.

idGroup.fg: They kidnapped me in the store.

txGroup.tx: Rukidnap ki kineu me rumsag kineu pak,

idGroup.fg: They kidnapped me and they carried me to-,

txGroup.tx: rutao na Coca Cola me ipitlak sliping pil em̃rom.

idGroup.fg: they gave me Coca Cola with a sleeping pill in it.

txGroup.tx: Me amatur em̃rom loto, me rupan rutau kineu natkon iskei,

idGroup.fg: I slept in the car and they took me to this village,
called Pulakan, a long way.

txGroup.tx: Mary ito Hotel, iler pak Hotel pa, me ito pan 6 klok kotfan, go

idGroup.fg: Mary was at the hotel, she went back to the hotel, but it was nearly six in the evening, and

txGroup.tx: ileka ata pan mau ipanik go ipreg inkwaeri pan pan pam̃ori na apuel.

idGroup.fg: she saw I wasn't back, she panicked and made inquiries and found I was missing.

txGroup.tx: Apuel sto rulek kineu pag skot nam̃er ne,

idGroup.fg: I wasn't at the shop, but they saw me climb into a car with this man,

txGroup.tx: go inom san, rumer ta lek kineu mau.

idGroup.fg: and that's all, they didn't see me again.
Anyway, they found me,
at one o'clock in the morning.

txGroup.tx: Eleven klok p̃og kin rupam̃or kineu me wan klok kin

idGroup.fg: At 11 pm they found me, but at one am

txGroup.tx: loto imai po mai mai mai po mos kineu, nlaken em̃ae.

idGroup.fg: the car came to get me, it was a long way.

txGroup.tx: Ale apo mai olwei pak hospitel pan rudren ki nrak welkia glukos a.

idGroup.fg: OK, I went to the hospital and they drained my blood because of glucose.

txGroup.tx: Me dokta ina, "Ku laki a, nlaken kum̃ol."

idGroup.fg: The doctor said, "You are lucky because you are alive."
(NT) Did they steal something?

txGroup.tx: (TK) Rupnak mane, go kompiuta softwe neu plak su ni teesa,

idGroup.fg: (TK) They took money and my computer software and kids' shoes
and my shoes that I had bought,
watch, sunglasses,

txGroup.tx: me am̃ol, go aler mai me gawankia.

idGroup.fg: but I was alive and I got back, that's it.

txGroup.tx: Ana ataf hospitel leg mai pak eroplen.

idGroup.fg: I left the hospital and went straight to the plane.
We went to the plane and returned.

txGroup.tx: Amer mai tkal Intercontinental go amer mes esan.

idGroup.fg: I went to play at the Intercontinental.
I played until 1991 and I finished.

txGroup.tx: Ana anom Intercontinental go 1991 pan tkal 1993

idGroup.fg: I finished at he Intercontinental and 1991 to 1993

txGroup.tx: ato esum̃ to nlaken apakot tete sernale nig nkas,

idGroup.fg: I stayed home because I bought everything to do with wood,

txGroup.tx: me ato weswes ki seserik ki nkas.

idGroup.fg: I worked a little with wood.

txGroup.tx: Me atu p̃al tu ata weswes mau.

idGroup.fg: I did nothing, I didn't work

txGroup.tx: 1993 go Mary ina, "E ilakor wi p̃afan weswes tete ofis, nlaken

idGroup.fg: In 1993 and Mary said, "It would be good if you worked in an office since

txGroup.tx: kupiatlak tetenamrun nranre ni ofis, na kutae weswes ofis me

idGroup.fg: you have good office skills, you know how to work in an office

txGroup.tx: kuipe to miusik teetwei mai, me malfane p̃atraem."

idGroup.fg: you've played music for a long time, but try working in an office."

txGroup.tx: Go alel nawesien, astat amer stat Hotel Le Lagon me alel nawesien.

idGroup.fg: I looked for work, I started at Le Lagon and I looked for work.

txGroup.tx: Apaoski nawesien pan pan apan tkal taon me san ata paoski nawesien mau,

idGroup.fg: I asked for work all over the town but a place I hadn't asked called for me,
they called for me.

txGroup.tx: Go rutelefon, Jif Jastis ni kot inrogo na ato lel nawesien.

idGroup.fg: They telephoned, the Chief Justice heard I was looking for work.

txGroup.tx: Go itelefon pak Mary me ipaos kin na, "Kutae nrik maarik gaag ki na kemai. Amur katraus skoti."

idGroup.fg: He rang Mary and said, "You tell your husband to come. I want to talk to him."

txGroup.tx: Apan traus skoti ana, "Ore apes ki English, Franis."

idGroup.fg: I went to talk with him and told him I speak English and French.

txGroup.tx: Ipo traem kineu, test ki kineu.

idGroup.fg: He tried me, he tested me.

txGroup.tx: Kompiuta itraem kompiuta, me nlaken kineu ateetwei teetwei mai ga apiatlak kompiuta mai nlaken ato mur sernale ni elektronik.

idGroup.fg: He tried my computer skills, but as I had a computer years ago he saw that I liked electronic things.

txGroup.tx: Go ipam̃ori na ntaewen neu nanre ni kompiuta iwi.

idGroup.fg: He saw that I knew about computers.

txGroup.tx: Go apo taep naenti wod per minet.

idGroup.fg: And I could type ninety words per minute.

txGroup.tx: Go kalkulet fast, nanre ni kalkuleting masin go akaonting.

idGroup.fg: And calculate fast, on a calculating machine and in accounting.

txGroup.tx: Go ina, "O, gawankia, ag kin amur ag, me p̃afo tae stat gas?"

idGroup.fg: And he said, "When can you start?"

txGroup.tx: Go ana, "Ito akam." Okay, rurikrut, rupreg advetismen

idGroup.fg: And I said, "It's up to you."They recruited, they advertised

txGroup.tx: ga me ipo inteviu ki tete nakon

idGroup.fg: They interviewed some others

txGroup.tx: me itili na, "Akano promis me p̃afo traem."

idGroup.fg: and he said, "I can't promise, but we'll see."

txGroup.tx: Kofo traem komam ulakor pi siks, me kineu awin wes go apo pa.

idGroup.fg: There were about six of us but I won and I got the job.

txGroup.tx: Go aweswes kot stat 1993, pan tkal 1996, go arisaen.

idGroup.fg: I worked at the court from 1993 until 1996 then I resigned.
I resigned because I wanted to go to
the Chamber of Commerce.

txGroup.tx: Amro kin iwi nlaken amur kamer rediskava ki komesel ntaewen neu ni nanre ni, na, komes, a?

idGroup.fg: I thought it was good because I could rediscover my commercial training.

txGroup.tx: Go bisnes. Komam upat, komam upat kin upan inteviu, upan inteviu.

idGroup.fg: And business. There were four of us who did the interview.

txGroup.tx: Ale amer win wes. Go ga wankia pan tkal mees ato Chamber of Commerce, taos arisej,

idGroup.fg: And I got the job. Until today I work at the Chamber of Commerce as a researcher,

txGroup.tx: tred and invesmen, go infomesen ofisa.

idGroup.fg: trade and investment and information officer.

txGroup.tx: Go asemsem nlaken aweswes naor ilaap

idGroup.fg: And I am happy because I work in lots of places

txGroup.tx: go apitlak ntaewen neu iwelkia imer top nanre ni sernale fserser, nlaken ata fneski skul neu mau,

idGroup.fg: I am learning lots of new things because I didn't finish school,

txGroup.tx: me aweswes panpan akraksok tete ntawen kin atik kin malpei.

idGroup.fg: but I worked and learned as I went.

txGroup.tx: Nlaken nawesien atkalir welkia rupi nawesien p̃afp̃of.

idGroup.fg: Because the work that I deal with is important.

txGroup.tx: Ale mal ilaap kafo mas pan saisei skot tete natam̃ol nen gar rupi ekspets mana.

idGroup.fg: Many times I meet with experts.

txGroup.tx: Nafet nawesien ne, go mal ilaap asat janis nen kin, apaoskir kin nen rutijki kineu ki tenmatun.

idGroup.fg: Many times I take the chance and ask them to teach me things.

txGroup.tx: So gar rupitlak teori naor nen ruplaksok kineu welkia ato saisei skotir mana.

idGroup.fg: They had theory that they taught me when I met with them.

txGroup.tx: Go ruto tau ntaen nen kin, mees asemsem, nlaken apitlaken.

idGroup.fg: They give me some skills. Today I am happy because I have them.

txGroup.tx: Go ato Chamber of Commerce tkal malfane.

idGroup.fg: And I am at the Chamber of Commerce until today.

txGroup.tx: Komam nen kin upi tiawi ulek nam̃olien pei mai paakor nam̃olien ni mees.

idGroup.fg: We old people we look at the way of life before coming through to today.

txGroup.tx: Me nam̃olien ni mees imsal top. Itap taos nam̃olien ni malpei mau.

idGroup.fg: Life today is different. It isn't like life in those days.

txGroup.tx: Nam̃olien ni mees teesa rumetmatu wi,

idGroup.fg: Today, children are clever,

txGroup.tx: ruskul wi me rukano paketan ki tiawi.

idGroup.fg: they go to school, but they don't respect the old people.
They can't hear the language (they can't hear what their old people tell them).

txGroup.tx: Nlaken rumro na gar rumetmatu tol tiawi.

idGroup.fg: Because they think they know more than the old people.

txGroup.tx: Me tenen tiawi rutae ipi tesees.

idGroup.fg: But what the old people know is small.
The old people don't know more.

txGroup.tx: Me rumroperkat, runrog perkat nale tiawi nigmam tenen rupi tem mom go rait mom.

idGroup.fg: But they remember the wisdom of our old people, those who were our fathers and mothers.
We can't criticise them,

txGroup.tx: unrog naler, rutil tenamrun, komam upregi taosi kin gar rutli.

idGroup.fg: we listen to them, they tell us things, we do as they tell us.

txGroup.tx: Me mees, nam̃olien ni mees kineu kafo to pes.

idGroup.fg: But the life of today, this is what I always say.

txGroup.tx: Til tenen iwi, tenen ileg, me gar rukano rukano nrogo.

idGroup.fg: Say some things are good, some things are right, but they don't listen.

txGroup.tx: Nlaken rumrokin na gar rumetmatu tol nametmatuan nigmam tiawi.

idGroup.fg: Because they think their wisdom is better than that of our old people.

txGroup.tx: Me komam ukano pregsa kir nlaken ipi nafsan iskei nen kin tiawi kefo tafnau teesa.

idGroup.fg: But we can't criticise them because its the way that the old people teach young people.

txGroup.tx: Teesa ipreg tenamrun nen ikerkerai itakel me tenen kin ipi rait ko tiawi ukano preg kerkerai kir.

idGroup.fg: Children follow their own strong, crooked way, but their mothers and old people can't be strong with them.

txGroup.tx: Go ukano pes sa kir nlaken gar rukfo develop ki mal wi nen kefo mai.

idGroup.fg: We can't talk badly to them because they are developing their future.

txGroup.tx: Kafo traus tete natrauswen taos na naur malnen uto naur sees Erakor.

idGroup.fg: I will tell the story of when we were on the small island of Erakor.

txGroup.tx: Komam uta weswes skot loto mau.

idGroup.fg: We didn't work with cars.

txGroup.tx: Komam utap weswes skot enjin mau.

idGroup.fg: We didn't work with engines.

txGroup.tx: Uweswes ki narmom uweswes ki masmes p̃ur, uweswes ki kram,

idGroup.fg: We worked with our hands, with knives, with axes,
and we carried things on our heads.
We carried things on our backs,
we carried them on our shoulders.

txGroup.tx: Uto em̃ae uslasol mai pak elau. Loto itik.

idGroup.fg: We were a long way away, we carried things down to the sea. No cars.

txGroup.tx: Komam uweswes ki nar mam, ufarfar ki nam̃ol mam, raki nawesien p̃afp̃of laap.

idGroup.fg: We worked with our hands, we moved our bodies, for hard work.

txGroup.tx: Tiawi rukfo tai raru, ruweswes ki kram m̃as, rutap wesweski engine mau.

idGroup.fg: The old people cut canoes, they worked with only an axe, they didn't work with engines.

txGroup.tx: Mes, nam̃olien ni mees, kafo preg nawesien kafo sat nafnag ipatu napu.

idGroup.fg: Today, life today, I'll do work, I'll carry food and put it on the road.

txGroup.tx: Me kafo preg loto kefan msagi mai. Me malpei itik.

idGroup.fg: Then I get the truck to carry the things. But not in those days.

txGroup.tx: Nam̃olien nen kin tu pato mees ne itik malpei.

idGroup.fg: Life today is not like it was before.

txGroup.tx: Komam uweswes umaos umurin na koto wi, kofo pei maos.

idGroup.fg: We worked and we got tired, if we want to stay well, we would first have to get tired.

txGroup.tx: Nkal ni mam rumap̃rap̃or, uslat nanrogtesan itop.

idGroup.fg: Our clothes were ripped, we had too many hardships.

txGroup.tx: Me kofo pei inrok to wi. Kofo sur kopra em̃ae, em̃ae.

idGroup.fg: We would then feel good. We worked copra, a long way.

txGroup.tx: Me kofo slati mai loto itik.

idGroup.fg: But we carried it, no car.

txGroup.tx: Kofo mai kofo pregi na, komer ler nkap, komai suekro.

idGroup.fg: We would go and make it, get firewood and smoke it.
Until it was dry, then we pounded it.

txGroup.tx: Me malnen rukoi pe laosok silua rutur pek. Natam̃ol kin kefo slati.

idGroup.fg: When they finished pounding it, they sewed up the bag. The man would take it.

txGroup.tx: Pan psi raru elau, kefo msagi pak sto,

idGroup.fg: Put it in the canoe on the beach, take it to Vila,

txGroup.tx: natam̃ol imaos top malpei, nlaken kin nam̃olien ni malpei ikerkerai, toklos teni nawesien.

idGroup.fg: people got tired in those days, because life then was hard, as regards the work.

txGroup.tx: Me raki nanrogperkatwen komam ukano tao nafsan ni tiawi, tarp̃ek,

idGroup.fg: But as for remembering, we can't ignore our old people's talk,

txGroup.tx: tiawi rupreg nafsan go rufla tili na kofan gar preg talm̃at, kofo pa.

idGroup.fg: the old people might tell us to go to the garden and we have to go.
We cannot ignore the words of our ancestors.

txGroup.tx: Na teni sup̃ ni nam̃olien ni malpei. Go mees kin ato trausi.

idGroup.fg: That was the way of life before. Like today that I am talking about it.
Of long ago.
Life before.
Come to today.

txGroup.tx: Nam̃olien kaaru ni mees ikerkerai top.

idGroup.fg: The other life today is too hard.

txGroup.tx: Go itaos malpei wel kin ufla salem ki kopra,

idGroup.fg: Like before when we would sell copra,

txGroup.tx: upiatlak taos malpei uius ki na Australia, mane ni Australia.

idGroup.fg: before we used Australian money.
One pound, ten shillings, like that.

txGroup.tx: Me ipi mane p̃ur, mane p̃ur.

idGroup.fg: But it was big money, big money.

txGroup.tx: Kofo slati pak sto, ufla sat ten slen pak sto.

idGroup.fg: We would take it to town, we would take ten shillings.

txGroup.tx: Kofo pakot tete namurien nigmam kenom me kotfak mane kofo sati ler mai. Nlaken prais ises m̃as.

idGroup.fg: We would buy what we wanted, but we would have change to take back. Because the price was very low.

txGroup.tx: Ko ufla sat wan paon pak sto, mani p̃ur, mani p̃ur.

idGroup.fg: And if we took a pound to town, it was big money, big money.

txGroup.tx: Kofo sat tep̃ur ler, me kofo paakot ki tesees.

idGroup.fg: I would take a lot, but I would spend a little.

txGroup.tx: Me malfanen sernale ipak elag, pak elag, pak elag.

idGroup.fg: But today everything is high, high, high.

txGroup.tx: Go taos nanre nigmam tiawi ukano piatlak mani nlaken nam̃olien ni mees ikerkerai.

idGroup.fg: And as for us old people we can't have much money because life today is too hard.

txGroup.tx: Komam kofo kerkerai preg nawesien sees go kofo tae pam̃or mani.

idGroup.fg: We need to work hard and we can get money.

txGroup.tx: Me ifwel kin uta kerkerai weswes mau ukano pam̃or mani.

idGroup.fg: But if we don't work hard we can't get any money.

txGroup.tx: Go malpei komam kofo tae welu tiawi.

idGroup.fg: Before, we used to help the old people.

txGroup.tx: Tiawi ifla pan sur kopra ipatu komam natam̃ol kerkerai kofo tae pan gar slati mai.

idGroup.fg: The old people would cut copra, and we strong ones would go and get it for them.
But not today.

txGroup.tx: Iwel kafla tp̃eki tete teesa kefa neu preg talm̃at,

idGroup.fg: If I tell some kids to work in the garden for me,

txGroup.tx: me kafo mas- kafo gar kuk, ko tete nrak atp̃olu tete natam̃ol p̃tae.

idGroup.fg: I have to cook for them, and sometimes I send someone else.

txGroup.tx: Kafo paaktofir iwel kafitlak mani kafo paaktofir.

idGroup.fg: I have to pay them if I have money I have to pay them.

txGroup.tx: Me wel atik ki mani kafo pan lel nafnag talm̃at kafo gar preg.

idGroup.fg: But if I have no money, I will go to the garden and get food for them.
Life today is like that.

txGroup.tx: Or ga itaos malpei nmatu komam umtaki taos nkal ni nanwei?

idGroup.fg: In the olden days women couldn't wear men's clothes.

txGroup.tx: Komam ukano kal ki nkal ni nanwei.

idGroup.fg: We couldn't wear men's clothes.

txGroup.tx: Ikerkerai, nen kin nmatu ikal ki nkal ni nanwei.

idGroup.fg: It was strong, that a woman dress in men's clothes.

txGroup.tx: Go mees mees nmatu me nanwei rukal pitkaskei.

idGroup.fg: And today, today, women and men dress the same.

txGroup.tx: Me komam malpei ukano kal ki nkal ni nanwei.

idGroup.fg: But back then we couldn't dress in men's clothes.

txGroup.tx: Ko kukal ki nkal ni mam nmatu.

idGroup.fg: And you wore women's clothes.

txGroup.tx: Me esan ni nigmam ikano paakor

idGroup.fg: But here [indicating her knees] couldn't show.

txGroup.tx: Nap̃utuok ikano paakor nkal neu kemas pram pak esa.

idGroup.fg: My knee couldn't show, my clothes must be long down to here.

txGroup.tx: Nkal neu kefo pram. Me iwel ag kuto esago.

idGroup.fg: My dress would be long. But if you were there.

txGroup.tx: Ag kutotan sago me kineu amurin na kataf, o, ikerkerai top.

idGroup.fg: You sit there, but I want to leave (past you), oh it is very hard.

txGroup.tx: Kafo mtak. Kafo puetsok nakte nkal wel atuleg me ana kataf.

idGroup.fg: I would be scared. I would hold my skirt like this, I would stand up to leave.
I would walk.

txGroup.tx: Mailum siwer nrookot wok. Nlaken ag kuto.

idGroup.fg: Walk slowly in front of you. Because you are there.

txGroup.tx: Kafo pak etan kik. Nmatu itefla.

idGroup.fg: I will respect you. For women that is the way.

txGroup.tx: Ko natam̃ol laap rutu me nmatu imurin na kesiwer tol nlaken nanwei laap rutu.

idGroup.fg: Or if many men are there and a woman wants to walk past because many men are there.

txGroup.tx: Kefo nrok puetsok nkal ga ipak etan, nen kin kemailum tol nanwei.

idGroup.fg: She will bend low, and hold her dress, show respect so that she can slowly pass a man.

txGroup.tx: Ko wel nanwei rufla pi tap̃ou tu esa me nmatu imai, kefo pan lfek ur em̃ae.

idGroup.fg: Or if there are many men here, but a woman comes, she will go around them a long way.
Because she respects men.
The old way is like that.

txGroup.tx: Nmatu rutefla. Ko apak esum̃ tap, natam̃ol kin ruipe pur tu.

idGroup.fg: Women are like that. If I go to church, it is already full of people.

txGroup.tx: Kafo siwer kafo mailum nrok pan totan.Tefla.

idGroup.fg: I will walk, I will slowly bend and sit down. Like that.

txGroup.tx: Go taos nmatu komam utap kal taos mees mau. Nmatu ukal ki nkal nen narum ipram esa.

idGroup.fg: We women didn't dress like today. Women dressed in dresses with sleeves down to here (wrists).

txGroup.tx: Nawesien ni nafnag ipi nawesien ni nmatu. Nmatu kin ipreg nafnag.

idGroup.fg: Food work is women's work. Women make the food.

txGroup.tx: Tetenrak nanwei inrom nmatu ileka nmatu imaos go nanwei ipo welua.

idGroup.fg: Sometimes, if a man feels sorry for a woman he will see she is tired and the man will help her.

txGroup.tx: Me nafregnafnagwen sernrak ipi nmatu kin ipreg nafnag.

idGroup.fg: But getting food ready is always women's work.

txGroup.tx: Nmatu kin ikuk, nmatu kin ipuuri, ipreg kapu.

idGroup.fg: Women cook, women prepare laplap, make laplap.

txGroup.tx: Me nanwei ga kefo pak etalm̃at, islat nafnag ipaunamru kemai psi esum̃, me nmatu kin kefo preg nafnag.

idGroup.fg: The man would go to the garden, get food, carry it and put it in the house, but the woman prepares the food.

txGroup.tx: {edited} Nanwei ke fo pan lel nafnag, slat sernale mai pak esum̃, me nmatu kin kefo preg kapu esum̃. {/edited}

idGroup.fg: Men would go and get the food, carry everything back to the house, and women would make laplap at the house.

txGroup.tx: Me mees nmatu kemur kefuuri kefreg kapu, ga kefan tmen slat nafnag.

idGroup.fg: But today it is the woman who prepares food, makes laplap, who fetches food.

txGroup.tx: Kefan tmen lel nrau ketmen lel nm̃arteu, nkap, mai pak esum̃ kemer preg nafnag.

idGroup.fg: She goes herself to find laplap leaves, to look for dry coconuts, firewood, and comes back to the house to prepare the food.

txGroup.tx: Mees itefla. Sup̃ ni natam̃ol ni mees itefla. Me malpei, itik.

idGroup.fg: Today it is like that. People's customs are like that. But before, no.

txGroup.tx: Nanwei kefo pan lel nafnag, slat sernale mai pak esum̃, me nmatu kin kefo preg kapu esum̃.

idGroup.fg: The man would look for food, bring everything back to the house, but the woman would make laplap at the house.

txGroup.tx: Me iwel rapan preg talm̃at. Ranru pan preg talm̃at.

idGroup.fg: So they both went and worked in the garden.

txGroup.tx: Me rekin kin kefan sat nafnag etalm̃at mai pak esum̃.

idGroup.fg: But as for how they took food from the garden to the house.

txGroup.tx: Nanwei kefo pan sat nafnag, me nmatu kefo preg nafnag. Kefo kuk ki, ko ipreg kapu. Tefla.

idGroup.fg: The man would get food, but the woman would prepare it. She would cook it, or make laplap. That's the way.

txGroup.tx: Nmatu ito esum̃ ilekor teesa, go taos malpei nmatu rutap pak hospitel mau.

idGroup.fg: Women stay home and look after children, and in the olden days they didn't go to hospital at all.

txGroup.tx: Komam upiatlak tiawi, tiawi nen kin gar me ruto raki nen kin rulekor nmatu, nen kin ruslat teesa.

idGroup.fg: We have old people who helped and looked after a woman when she had a baby.
Only at home.

txGroup.tx: Ipiatlak Liaas, Limat, Ana, Sera, Pali.

idGroup.fg: There was Liaas, Limat, Ana, Sera, Pali.

txGroup.tx: Gar nen ruto lekor nmatu esum̃.

idGroup.fg: They looked after women at home.

txGroup.tx: Nmatu imur na keslat teesa. Rupan sosor rumai.

idGroup.fg: When women wanted to have a baby. They went and called them to come.

txGroup.tx: Skotir me rupo sel teesa rulekor wer esum̃. Pan pan rukerkerai.

idGroup.fg: With them, but they would take the child and look after it at home. Until they were strong.

txGroup.tx: (NT) Me teesa ipaakor ni nasum̃ nen?

idGroup.fg: (NT) Were children born at home?

txGroup.tx: (TT) Itik (NT) Malpei? (TT) Malpei, malpei nasum̃ tefla nen m̃as. Nasum̃ kapa itik.

idGroup.fg: (TT) No (NT) Before? (TT) Before, in the home, like that. There were no tin houses.

txGroup.tx: Rupaakor na, nasum̃ nen kin rowat, sum̃ rowat.

idGroup.fg: They were born in thatch houses.

txGroup.tx: A.A. Naliati ilim, faef dei, nmatu imas pnut to

idGroup.fg: For five days the woman must stop quiet.

txGroup.tx: Go nmatu ikano taos mees. Nmatu ipan sel teesa hospitel.

idGroup.fg: And a women can't do what she does today. A woman has her baby in the hospital.

txGroup.tx: Sel teesa mees, kotfan itae tuleg pan was, ko ikuk.

idGroup.fg: Have the baby today, in the afternoon she gets up and washes, or cooks.

txGroup.tx: Me malpei itik nmatu malen tiawi itoraki nmatu iskei islat teesa.

idGroup.fg: But not then, the old women waited for a woman to have her baby.

txGroup.tx: Kefo mas pnut to ikano farfar.

idGroup.fg: She must keep still, not move about.

txGroup.tx: Go nmatu nen kin taos Sera ifla to raki nmatu iskei.

idGroup.fg: And the woman, like Sera, would wait with a woman.

txGroup.tx: Nmatu nen imailum pnuto. Ga kefo ga preg teesa kelos.

idGroup.fg: The woman would stay there quiet. And she would bathe the child.

txGroup.tx: Kega klin ki teesa. Go iklin ki raiten.

idGroup.fg: Would clean the child for her. And she would wash the mother.

txGroup.tx: Raiten ikano tuleg pan los, kemas pnut to pan pan naliati ilim inom.

idGroup.fg: The mother couldn't stand to wash, she had to sit quiet for five days.

txGroup.tx: Go rait teesa kefo tae toleg preg tete namrun sees.

idGroup.fg: And the mother of the child would be able to stand and do small things.

txGroup.tx: Me ikano pan pai nasok, ikano pan kuk, pan kefei piatlak wik inru itol.

idGroup.fg: But she can't clean up rubbish, she can't cook, until two or three weeks.

txGroup.tx: Ko tete nrak nmatu ilekor ptaki nmatu nen islat teesa,

idGroup.fg: And sometimes the woman looking after the mother who had a baby,

txGroup.tx: itae skoti to atlag mau iskei.

idGroup.fg: she can stay with her for a whole month.

txGroup.tx: Pan nmatu ipiatlak nakerkeraian go [teesa itae nen kin-] mama ga kefo tae tmen lekor wes.

idGroup.fg: Until the woman goes into labour and [the child knows-] the mother knows how to look after herself.

txGroup.tx: Go ipo pa. Ale, nanwei kefo mer pei preg nafnag pan pan pan, welkia imer preg kastom tu doctor,

idGroup.fg: Then she can go. Then her husband will make food and will make kastom to the doctor,
to the woman who looked after his wife.

txGroup.tx: Kega preg nafnag. Preg nafsawian tua. "Kuneu lekor ptaki nmatu neu isel teesa.

idGroup.fg: He makes food ready for her. He gives thanks. "You looked after my wife for me when she had a baby.

txGroup.tx: Malfanen rato wi. Nta kafo tuok gaag m̃iit." Itua m̃iit, ko itua tete nafnag, ko itua tete nkal ko mane.

idGroup.fg: Now they are well. I will give you a mat." He gives her a mat or he gives her some food, some clothes, or some money.

txGroup.tx: Ale kefo ga slati me kefo pan psi esum̃ ga, itefla.

idGroup.fg: Then he will go and take it for her, and put it in her house, like that.

txGroup.tx: Malpei komam teesa laap rupaakor. Nanre ni paptais.

idGroup.fg: In those days lots of kids were born. As for baptism.

txGroup.tx: Mal ni, mal ni tiawi, tiawi. Tiawi ni teetwei atap tae mau,

idGroup.fg: The old people. The old people from long ago I don't know,

txGroup.tx: me tiawi nen kin taos, rupi tem mom,

idGroup.fg: but those who were our father,
and mother, they baptised.

txGroup.tx: Go ipiatlak pasta Sope, pasta Saurei.

idGroup.fg: There was pastor Sope and pastor Saurei.

txGroup.tx: Gar nen kin me malpei, malpei kotkot misnari ipreg nfaptaiswen.

idGroup.fg: They, long long ago, the missionaries did the baptisms.

txGroup.tx: Mista McKenzie kin rumai. Rupaptais. Go rutousok natam̃ol.

idGroup.fg: Mister McKenzie came. They baptised. And they married people.

txGroup.tx: (NT) Go sup̃ ni teesa nmatu go sup̃ ni teesa nanwei ipitkaskei?

idGroup.fg: (NT) Do girls and boys have the same fashion?

txGroup.tx: (TT) Itik. Iwel kineu afla preg asel.

idGroup.fg: (TT) No. If I were to make a friend.
I have a boyfriend, I would be scared.

txGroup.tx: Taos amurin na kafestafi akano pestafi.

idGroup.fg: If I want to talk to him, I can't talk to him.

txGroup.tx: Preg taktmokit lek nrae kit, itik.

idGroup.fg: Face to face, no.

txGroup.tx: Kafo preg leta, kafo mtir natus, kamtir natus wel amurin na kafestaf boyfriend neu akano trau leg pan leka. Akano.

idGroup.fg: I would write a letter as I wanted to talk to him, but I can't talk directly to him. I can't.

txGroup.tx: Kafo preg leta keskei. Ale atu naat, "P̃afo neu tuaki."

idGroup.fg: I will write a letter. Then I give it to someone, "You will give it to him for me."

txGroup.tx: Ko ga ifla murin na ketao tete nanromien sees, ikano trau leg mai tao.

idGroup.fg: And if he wanted to give me a little present, he can't just come and give it to me.

txGroup.tx: Kefo preg nanromien nen keur tete naor ptae. Me rakin kin komam ratrau tmom nrae ki komam,

idGroup.fg: He will take the present to different places. But as for us giving it face to face,
it's fear, ah?

txGroup.tx: Tefla, nigmam malpei itefla, ukano trau iwel kineu ato esa, me boyfriend neu ifla paakor tenaor ni esanpe kineu asef apan ur em̃ae.

idGroup.fg: Like, for us, then, it was like this, we couldn't just, if I was here, but my boyfriend came out here somewhere, I would run away, I would run a long way.

txGroup.tx: Sup̃ ni malpei itefla. Mees welkia boyfriend, puserek naor iskei, a. Me malpei ga, ga ikerkerai.

idGroup.fg: The way it was back then. Today, as for a boyfriend, talking in the same place. But in those days it was strong.

txGroup.tx: Iwel rakfo siwer kaaru ipa go kaaru ipa me natus m̃as kin rapas tmom pestaf komam ki natus.

idGroup.fg: If we were walking, one here, one here, but only paper would pass between us, talk by letter.

txGroup.tx: Ko tete nanromien sees me iwelkin ifpi namurien ni tem go rait na namurien ni teesa iwi.

idGroup.fg: Or some small present, but if the parents agree with the child, it's okay.

txGroup.tx: Go malfane, tem teesa nanwei ga kefo pak esum̃ ni tem teesa nmatu,

idGroup.fg: And now, the father of this boy would go to the house of the girl's father,

txGroup.tx: kefaos ki, kefo paoski, "Kutrok na teesa nanwei neu kefo taulu teesa nmatu gaag?" Iwel tem ina, "Ore, iwi."

idGroup.fg: to ask him, "Do you agree that my son will marry your daughter?" If the father says, "Yes, it is good."
Now they will marry each other.

txGroup.tx: Me welkin tem teesa nanwei ifla pan me tem teesa nmatu ifla mal kefo mer ler.

idGroup.fg: But if the boy's father goes but the girl's father doesn't want it, he will go back again.

txGroup.tx: Kefo mer ler pan kefo sos teesa nanwei ga.

idGroup.fg: He will go and he will call his son.

txGroup.tx: Kefo sos teesa nanwei ga me kefo nrikinkin na, "Kineu kaipe pan gaag paoski teesa nmatu."

idGroup.fg: He will go back and call his son. and say to him, "I went and asked for that girl for you."

txGroup.tx: Me raiten ifla mal ko tmen ifla mal kin ag kupiatlaken.

idGroup.fg: But if her mother doesn't want it, or her father doesn't want it, that you have her.

txGroup.tx: Go imer nom. Itap pregi nen kin, "Kafo preg kerkeraiki nen kafo pueti." Tik.

idGroup.fg: It is over. He doesn't say, "I will force them so that I can have her." No.

itmGroup.ti: William Wayane, a story of his life

txGroup.tx: Histri neu malen kin api teesa mai tkal mees.

idGroup.fg: My history, from when I was a child until today.

txGroup.tx: Papa neu ga ipi evangelist iskei teetwei, go ito siwer ur naurur preg nawesien tap.

idGroup.fg: My father was an evangelist then, and he went around the islands to do religious work.

txGroup.tx: Ipi nlaken kineu apo paakor naur nig Erromango,

idGroup.fg: That is why I was born on Erromango island,

txGroup.tx: malen papa neu ipato weswes ur Emlakul.

idGroup.fg: before my father was working on Malakula.

txGroup.tx: Nafioson ipan nag keler mai pak naur Erakor.

idGroup.fg: The call went out for him to come back to Erakor island.

txGroup.tx: Go malnen imai tkal naur Erakor

idGroup.fg: And when he got to Erakor Island

txGroup.tx: go rumer soso nen kefak naur nig saot Erromango

idGroup.fg: they then called him to go to south Erromango
